PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The minister will recall that when the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, brought down his One Nation package, he promised to relieve the tax burden on middle income earners—particularly those on incomes between $20,000 and $40,000—by bringing in the infamous l-a-w tax cuts. Minister, I remind you also that today we learned that only Australians earning more than $70,000 a year enjoy a lower tax burden than they did in 1983 and that in fact low and middle income families are now paying more tax. Is this what Mr Keating meant when he said, `This is as good as it gets'? Or is this yet another broken promise and a further demonstration of why this government deserves a spell on the bench?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Hill, coming from the opposition, should raise the question of taxation, because when John Howard was Treasurer of this country, the tax system of Australia was a national disgrace. Wealthy people in this country paid tax if they chose to. The burden of taxation fell on middle and low income earners in this country. Sir Garfield Barwick in the High Court smiled on this system. It was a massive rort, and we remember the bottom-of-the-harbour as a national disgrace. That is your legacy; that is what you delivered. The report in today's Australian is a report on our reforms and achievements held not against your model of disgrace but against an ideal model—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. Consistent with what you have said to us in the past, we have given the minister time to introduce his answer. But now I remind him that the question is about his government's record and its broken promises on taxation. I invite him to answer that question for the benefit of the Australian people.
—I must say that when questions are asked in that form, they invite such responses. But I would ask the minister to get to the point of the answer.

—Mr President, the other mistruth in this question is about l-a-w, law. We delivered the first tranche of those tax cuts six months ahead of time, and we delivered the second tranche of those tax cuts in the form of payment for superannuation in the last budget, and that is the most responsible way in which it can be done. So let us not have this cant and hypocrisy from the opposition about l-a-w, law. Our promises have been delivered, unlike your `fistful of dollars' promise in the 1977 election when you tried to bribe the Australian people by offering tax cuts which you did not deliver. We have provided seven rounds of tax cuts during the period of our government.

PARA.TAB: I will turn now to the subject under discussion, the report in today's Australian. Might I say that Treasury cannot confirm any of the calculations in the model. Treasury regards that as a flawed model, as misrepresenting and selective and not able to stand up to rigorous analysis in Australia. I remind senators that, under us, Australia has become the second lowest taxed country of the 24 OECD countries.

Importantly, if we go to the report in today's paper, the biggest flaw in it is to include the superannuation guarantee levy as if that were a tax. If that were excluded, middle income earners would be much better off. Indeed, George Megalogenis, the correspondent for the Australian, says in his own analysis:
Those on average earnings of $28,348 a year are paying just $4 a week less in income tax now than they did in 1985 . . .

ANSWER.PARA: They are the remarks of the Australian's own analysis, which do not support the premise of your question, Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: But why should the superannuation guarantee levy be included? It is not a tax. It is certainly not a tax; superannuation is, of course, deferred income for ordinary Australians. It is money not provided to the government, like it may be in other countries. It is money not held by the government, like it might be in other countries. It is money that belongs to the individual and to the worker, not like in other countries. It is their money; not the government's. That is why the OECD regard the superannuation guarantee levy as not a tax. The opposition, who obviously want to use the argument presented in today's paper to suit their own conniving political ends, do not respect the OECD or, indeed, the true character of the superannuation guarantee levy.

In the 10 years since we introduced tax reform in this country, the overall revenue for individuals has fallen from 13.5 per cent of GDP to 12 per cent of GDP. That is the record: under you, 13.5 per cent; under us, a fall to 12 per cent. When the coalition was in government, as I said, the tax system in this country was a national joke and a disgrace. The wealthy paid tax if they chose. The burden was on the middle income earners and the low income earners of Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the minister's attention been drawn to media reports claiming that the rural sector is not capable of sustaining high rates of growth? Can the minister inform the Senate about the state of the rural economy?

—I have seen those statements claiming that the rural sector was not capable of contributing to Australia's growth. The statements were made by Senator Ian Macdonald and, of course, therefore, are flatly wrong. Senator Ian Macdonald does not know what he was talking about. As I pointed out to the Senate in some documents I tabled recently, even the State Director of the Queensland Liberal Party was constrained to write a letter to the Townsville Bulletin saying that Senator Macdonald did not know what he was talking about when he was discussing the coalition.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald is equally ignorant about Australia's rural sector. The rural sector in many areas of Australia has been suffering from prolonged and crippling drought which has, understandably, undermined growth rates in that sector. But that is a very different matter to claiming that the sector is fundamentally unable to respond when external factors, such as seasonal conditions and prices, recover—that was the point Senator Macdonald was trying to make.

ABARE today issued its latest quarterly outlook for the rural and resources sector. ABARE's main finding is that the rural sector will experience both rising prices and output levels in 1995-96 leading to a very welcome increase in export values for the rural sector. As a result of rising international commodity prices on the back of continuing world growth and a return to more average production levels locally after the drought affected outcomes of the past years—as a result of all of that—there will be a very positive outlook for the contribution the rural sector will make to Australia's growth in terms of both rising exports and prices.

Specifically, ABARE forecasts a rise of around two per cent, production up a healthy 13.9 per cent, and rural exports up 5.5 per cent. The minerals resource sector is forecast to put in a strong performance, with export values set to rise by almost 20 per cent, Senator Macdonald.

The total value of commodity exports is forecast to rise by 14.1 per cent to $56.9 billion in 1995-96. Mineral resources are forecast to contribute $6 billion in increased value of these exports and rural commodities $1 billion. As I have just said, these ABARE forecasts published today do not reflect a sector with `little chance of contributing to national growth', as claimed by Senator Ian Macdonald. They make a mockery of his claims, although, in here, of course, we are getting very used to that.

The ABARE figures are underpinned by effective and clearly articulated government policies—something that the rural sector is still not getting from the opposition. Even in respect of such serious problems as drought, they are asking the questions and still getting no answers. Rural Australia is still waiting to hear any policy detail at all from this opposition, despite Senator Hill's boast, publicly made, that there are three folders stuffed full of opposition policies. Senator Hill, you have said publicly that you have got three folders stuffed full of opposition policies. It is about time you tabled them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the minister further confirm that a strong recovery is expected in the value of farm production from 1995 to 1996?

—I can. A big improvement in grain production is expected in 1995-96, with total winter grain production forecast to be 26.4 million tonnes, some 84 per cent up on 1994-95. This follows a large increase in winter plantings in Western Australia and southern grain growing areas. Dry warm weather with only patchy rainfall since sowing has unfortunately reduced your prospects for winter crops in Queensland and, as we know, despite recent rain, in northern New South Wales. These figures demonstrate that rural Australia is doing more than its fair share to contribute to national economy growth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Minister, in 1985 when Mr Keating was a leading advocate of reform of Australia's tax system, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Ordinary working people in Australia have . . . not only shouldered the entire burden of the increase in government spending, but they have also taken on board some of the burden previously paid by the upper income groups.

Minister, isn't it a fact that, 10 years later, Australian families continue to carry the burden of higher indirect taxes, that families continue to pay higher personal tax because Mr Keating broke his promise on the l-a-w tax cuts, and that families continue to pay higher home mortgages because we have the highest real interest rates in the world—all as a result of your government's inability to manage your debt and spending? Minister, will you tell Australian families what has changed since Mr Keating made his statement in 1985?

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, if this question is largely about tax, and it certainly seemed to be, it is wrongly directed to me and it probably should go to Senator Cook. Secondly, what does Senator Minchin mean by `Australian families'—Australian families this, Australian families that, with no distinguishing features about them at all?

PARA.TAB: Are you trying to make distinctions, Senator, between families where two parents work and families where one parent is at home, or are you talking about different incomes? We have already heard Senator Cook refer to the complete errors in the claim in an article published today about Australians paying more tax. On that evidence already, you would know that Australian families are much better off under this government.

But you ask what has changed since 1985 for families. Senator, let me start telling you a few of the things. We have thousands more child-care places that families with two parents working and families with one parent at home are now enjoying. That is one major change and benefit to Australian families. Secondly, as was the case in 1984 and certainly in 1985, none of the low income families in this country pay their Medicare levy. They are exempt from paying that, Senator, to assist them with the cost of health. Do you remember how those families could not go near the doctor before 1983 because two million of them were not insured? That is one of the other things that we have changed for Australian families.

Do you remember the changes in social security, Senator, with targeted payments for families, benchmark payments for children below 13 and above 13—benchmarked for the first time ever and indexed to change with inflation? These were enormous benefits for families. The introduction of the parenting allowance was a huge benefit to Australian families.

If you want to talk about what is of benefit to families, just remember, since you asked me, that these are just a few of the items. Consider what has happened to Australian families since we came into office. When we came to office, about 36 per cent—in the thirties—of children finished year 12. Now, around 80 per cent of children finish year 12. That is another thing Australian families really want for their children. Also, as of about next February families will be eligible for a maternity allowance on the occasion of the birth of a child, which is in recognition of the costs at that time in a family's life.

I was asked: what has this government done for families? That is an excellent question. I have barely skimmed the surface. There are many things this government has done for families. If you pick out some of those items without looking at the whole comprehensive picture, you will get it wrong. You cannot look at tax without looking at payments. You cannot look at the benefits to families without looking at the implications of the Accord and the social wage, the benefits of Medicare and the benefits of education, as well as those targeted payments. This government now pays to Australian families over $12 billion in payments. That goes to those very Australian families you were citing a minute ago as being in big trouble. The record stands for itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The minister will have heard and seen reports today that 20 foreigners, including three Australians, are being held by General Farah Aideed in the southern Somali town of Baidoa. What is the government doing to ensure that the three Australians being held hostage are safe and will soon be released?

—The Australian High Commission in Nairobi has reported that three Australians are among 20 foreigners being held in Baidoa in Somalia and unable to leave. They are being held by, as has been reported, the local faction leader, General Farah Aideed, who occupied the town of Baidoa on Sunday. The three Australians are an ABC journalist and two women NGO aid workers. Our reports are that the three Australians are presently safe.

PARA.TAB: I have been exploring this morning avenues to secure the early release of the hostages, including the possibility of getting a personal appeal from me to General Aideed, whom I met in Nairobi last year, and also to Mr Ali Mahdi, whom I met in Mogadishu. Mr Ali Mahdi becomes relevant because, of course, it has been the subject of speculation that he may himself be imminently about to mount a military attack on Baidoa in order to recover the territory just lost to General Aideed.

I have settled the terms of messages which are now, I think at this moment, being sent through some quite complicated communications channels. The basic message is to urge the relevant factions to ensure the safe release of the hostages as soon as humanly possible and to refrain from any further action which may compromise their safety.

There are some other contingency planning arrangements which are being made to keep lines of communication open and to assist in any way we can to ensure the safe release of the hostages. We will continue to work with the UN and other countries involved to try and get a peaceful solution of the immediate situation but the larger one as well. I should also add, finally, that the Somali aid coordination body has written to General Aideed seeking a guarantee for the safety of the foreigners and permission for them to be relocated from Baidoa by aircraft, which aircraft remains on stand-by in Nairobi for this purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The platform for action issued by the Beijing conference calls on governments to formally measure the value of women's unpaid work. Given this government's prodding of other nations at that conference to make concrete domestic commitments, how is the government going to translate this part of the Beijing platform into action? Does cabinet actually spend much time addressing the issue of the unpaid work of women and men? If you do measure the value of women's unpaid work, what are you then going to do with that information? Will you, for example, move to incorporate it into the national accounts?
—I am indebted to Senator Kernot for giving me at least a minute's notice of this.
—It is a question without notice.

—Some advance encouragement to give her a substantive answer is the way in which I would describe it. I can only partially meet that obligation. In relation to measuring unpaid work, however, I can say that Australia is very well advanced as compared with most other countries. The ABS conducts a five-yearly survey of unpaid work—the time use survey. The 1993 System of National Accounts recommends that the boundary of production could be extended by incorporating unpaid household work and voluntary and community work in so-called satellite accounts. The ABS supports this approach and is presently working towards its development.

PARA.TAB: As to the kinds of estimates that have been made as to the value of that work, in 1992 the estimated total value of unpaid work was $227.8 billion—that is to say, nearly 60 per cent of GDP; 58 per cent in fact. Unpaid household work contributed $209.7 billion of that. The remaining $18.1 billion was comprised of volunteer and community work. Those figures are published in the Australian Women's Yearbook, which Senator Kernot would no doubt be familiar with.

She did ask a couple of other things about what are we going to do with all those figures when we had them. I will seek advice on that to see what the present intentions are so far as the further statistical development is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have had 13 years to think about it.

—You can always offer us some policies of your own, Senator Hill. You would not want to break your duck, I know, but please feel free to share with us and the Australian community just what conceivably you might have in mind on this and 500,000 other things on which you can continue to wax cynically indignant. To the extent that there is anything more that can be said on this subject at this stage, I will be delighted to seek that information and make it available to Senator Kernot since she has asked her question today so nicely.

—OK—well try this one: would you acknowledge that the government is more likely to honour economic commitments made to forums such as APEC than it is to honour economic commitments made at forums like the Beijing forum?

—That is absolutely not fair at all. They are different forums addressing different policy issues. What we have been addressing in APEC are things like economic cooperation strategies, as Senator Schacht said yesterday, about small and medium enterprise business networks and, of course, the larger trade and investment facilitation and liberalisation agendas.

PARA.TAB: But there are many aspects of social policy at the borderline of economic and social policy which are very appropriately addressed in the context of conferences like this—in particular, the Copenhagen conference a few months ago on economic and social development issues in which the kinds of strategies that Australia has developed, for example, through the Working Nation white paper for getting long-term unemployed people back to work and so on, were seen as right at the cutting edge of international policy development. Equally, there is no doubt that conferences of this kind are extremely useful in getting a better appreciation of what is already going on by way of policy addressing these issues and also in opening up new items on the international agenda for us to pursue. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook. I understand that the IBM corporation has reached the end of its seven-year partnership program. Can the minister explain to the Senate what contribution the participation of IBM has made to the program and to the development of the information technology industry within Australia?
—What about Microsoft?

—Microsoft is going all right, thank you, Senator. The partnerships for development program was inaugurated by this government. It enables major international companies to have access to government contracts. It encourages them to form a partnership with the government in order to do research and development here, to locate manufacturing or other operations here, and to export from Australia and thus address some or our current account issues.

PARA.TAB: Today IBM graduated with distinction from the partnerships for development program. It has been in the program since 1988. As a consequence of that program and the partnership during that period, IBM exported $3 billion worth of equipment and product from Australia. In last year alone, it managed to export $550 million worth of information technology from Australia. This is an excellent example of how the government, working with major private sector companies, can target and influence the shape and size of an Australian industry and how the industry, basing itself in Australia on a competitive basis, can achieve major exports in the Asia-Pacific region.

Mr President, since the government launched its regional headquarters program just two years ago, 63 companies have now located their regional headquarters in Australia, with a total investment brought by them of $1.7 billion and the creation of just over 5,500 jobs for Australians. If we look at what has happened in the last three months, 21 information technology companies have committed $1.6 billion in manufacture and strategic investment to Australia. Much more than that is in the pipeline.

Over the next three months, another $2 billion that we know about will be committed for information technology investment in this country. That is an outstanding performance. Australia is emerging as one of the leading economies in this region for information technology—the biggest industry in the world, and the one set to grow the most.

When we came to power just over 13 years ago Australia had little industry in information technology to speak of. We exported less than $100 million per annum from this industry sector. It was in response to that quite appalling situation that we developed our strategy with the information technology companies to take on the world marketplace with a focus on research and development, manufacture and exports for the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —So why did you let Keating put you off?

—You don't like economic good news; Australians do. You are just out of step, Senator. Since then, to the year 1994, we have exported $2.4 billion in information technology products and services—a 2,400 per cent increase on what the coalition was able to deliver for this country and, as a consequence, a quite dramatic increase for the industry in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Sixty-five world-scale IT companies have now signed the partnerships agreements with the government. This represents a boost in exports and R&D of around $8 billion since the program commenced. It also means that Australians get real jobs in an industry of the future which is a brain-based industry and thus the jobs are more rewarding. The IT sector in Australia is forecast to grow from around $9.6 billion annually to $13.5 billion by 1998 and will employ 173,000 Australians when it achieves that situation.

Mr President, this program has worked well. We have forged good partnerships with the private sector. It has brought big investment to Australia that we otherwise would not have attracted. Research and development goes on in this country because of it. Manufacture and export from this country to the broader region occurs because of this program. I commend IBM for its investment and for working in this program with us, and all of the other IT companies in Australia which are reaping the benefits of this type of industry development program.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. You have frequently claimed that Australia has one of the lowest tax burdens in the OECD. Isn't that because the government fraudulently uses figures that include compulsory social security contributions in other OECD countries but do not include our compulsory superannuation charges? Isn't the OECD definition, which is not based on salaries confiscated by law, absurd in Australia's case? Isn't it really the case that we rank in the middle of the OECD in terms of our overall tax burden and that our position relative to other OECD countries has actually deteriorated since Labor's election in 1983?

—Mr President, these matters of comparative analysis are not a matter of Australia applying its own criteria and making up our own list. It is a matter of the OECD developing a list, developing the criteria, applying those criteria and producing the result that Australia is right down at the bottom of that particular list—the lowest and second-lowest taxed country in the whole of the developed universe.

PARA.TAB: That is the point, that is the answer to your particular question. You have simply misunderstood the way the system works. You have wilfully misunderstood it, I am prepared to assume—I cannot believe that you would be ignorant of the way in which these statistics are compiled, Senator—but I do think it is inappropriate in the circumstances to misstate the situation in that way. We are where we are on that list because we deserve to be by the OECD's own criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister would be aware of claims that the government is not doing enough to address the significantly high rates of unemployment that exist in certain Australian regions. Can the minister respond to these claims and can he point to any concrete initiatives to support his view?

—I thank Senator Jones for his question. Recently in Senator Jones's own state of Queensland, Mr Crean made announcements in the Wide Bay area about a number of new initiatives under the Working Nation program. Only last week in my own state of South Australia, Mr Crean made a number of announcements about employment projects which clearly reject any suggestion that we are not doing enough to address the unemployment problems in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Working Nation, as everybody knows, is a $9 billion commitment over four years. It is a comprehensive strategy that aims to share the benefits of economic and employment growth with both the long-term unemployed and the regions in which they live. By way of an example is my own state of South Australia. Some of the areas with higher unemployment than the average, of course, are the northern suburbs of Salisbury and Elizabeth. I was delighted to see that Minister Crean visited that area and was able to detail a series of initiatives that will lead to over 1,500 job opportunities in South Australia with many employers in the northern region—work which is an excellent outcome for that area.

Working Nation has made available $103 million in 1995-96, together with a framework to ensure that the Adelaide region continues to grow and generate employment and training opportunities. Last week, Minister Crean outlined the commitments by General Motors-Holden's and Lear Seating, two major manufacturers in the northern region, to develop 490 traineeships, which will have a major impact in that region. In addition, he was able to announce the government's commitment of $11.5 million to new work opportunities programs, which will see up to 1,000 long-term unemployed people engaged in revegetation and other related activities developing the state's national parks and reserves.

These initiatives demonstrate the success of Working Nation's approach. That is enabling the local community to identify employment projects that will create new jobs and provide skills and training for unemployed people. This, of course, is contrasted with the mean-spirited position of the opposition—who have no policy other than to cut government expenditure in this area and give no hope to those who are, unfortunately, unemployed. Of course, this is one reason why Mr Howard and his shadow ministry refused to make any detail available to the Australian public about their employment program—because they have none.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: does the government intend not only to bankroll Dr Lawrence's private legal action to scuttle the Western Australian royal commission but also to use taxpayers' funds to pay legal fees for representation in the commission over and above whatever the Western Australian government decides is fair and reasonable? If you are prepared to top up Dr Lawrence's legal fees for appearance before the commission, will you also answer why it is that Dr Lawrence should not, like any other litigant, be herself responsible for any costs of her representation in the commission that are not considered fair and reasonable by the Western Australian government?

—Mr President, it is not a matter of Dr Lawrence or anybody else being on a mission to scuttle the royal commission. It has been on a voyage of self-destruction almost since day one, and that is what we can all starkly witness as these absurd proceedings continue to play themselves out. I would have thought Senator Vanstone would have ample opportunity to ask the question she has just asked me at the hearing which is about to be resumed later today on this particular issue, when I will be in a position and happy to respond to her in more detail.

PARA.TAB: Might I say, in general terms, that the particular offer that has now been received from the Western Australian government is conspicuously small-minded and miserable in its extent. Not only does it not extend to the collateral proceedings which have been initiated by Dr Lawrence—the kind of collateral proceedings which the New South Wales government was perfectly happy to finance when Mr Greiner took on the validity of ICAC; the kind of collateral proceedings that the Tasmanian government was perfectly happy to finance when Mr Gray wanted to challenge certain aspects of the validity of the Rouse royal commission—not only has Mr Richard Court refused to go down that particular path, but he has also refused to support the legal costs that Dr Lawrence is incurring on a reasonable basis.

I have not got the details in front of me now—I was going to look at that between now and when we resume the hearing—but my recollection is there has been a financial limit set which is even lower than that which is normally payable for top silks in WA, that it has effectively excluded altogether reference to the kinds of rates that are being charged by interstate silks. There are a whole series of other limitations that have been set such as to create a very large gap indeed between the amount that is proposed to be offered for her funding support and that which has—

TALK.START.PARA: —She should have taken out better insurance then.

—She has: from the government. We are delivering. We are prepared to deliver because we are a little bit more honest and a little bit more decent in our approach to these matters than you lot ever would be. My understanding, although I need to check this further, is that the particular limits which have been set by Mr Court and his government are significantly more stringent than the criteria that have been applied in the past—certainly for those royal commissions for whose carriage the Labor government has been responsible. I will be in a position to answer those questions hopefully in a little more detail a little later, if you can curb your impatience and wait till then.

—Do I take, Minister, that you are now completely refusing to rule out topping up Dr Lawrence's legal fees for appearances before the commission? Do I take it by what you say that you are suggesting Dr Lawrence is getting some different treatment from the Western Australian government in terms of legal fees than anyone else appearing before the commission? Is she somehow being singled out for negative treatment by the Western government, or are you singling her out and topping up her bills in a way that no other former minister will have their bills topped up?

—I am not suggesting that she is being treated differently from other people currently before the commission. I do not know how other people are being treated. What I am suggesting is that on information available to me, which I will need to further check, she is being treated differently from the way in which previous people caught up in Western Australian royal commissions have been treated by previous governments; and treated in a way which, frankly, is mean spirited, miserable carping and exactly what one would expect from the kind of government that had the indecency and the hide to set in train this particular political ramp in the first place—an absolutely unprecedented royal commission which has served only to devalue the currency, the legitimacy, the effectiveness and the credibility of royal commissions in this country.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Family Services. Minister, I draw your attention to a press release by Senator McGauran titled `Call to dismiss childcare police', in which he attacks the National Child Care Accreditation Council and its quality improvement system. Is there any substance to the senator's claims?
—This has to be one of the most scurrilous and mischievous press releases ever put out, even by Senator McGauran.
—Big call.

—It is a big call, but he can match it, Senator. Senator McGauran wants to suggest that the National Child Care Accreditation Council should be dismissed because it is, according to him, going around the country practising intimidation and has something like 300 government reviewers patrolling child-care centres. This just shows what Senator McGauran does not know. Those reviewers are part of the process. They go to centres and assess whether a centre's self-assessment is accurate. They are not patrolling. They are assisting with the process involving the centres assessing whether or not they feel as though the quality they provide in their centres is adequate.

PARA.TAB: This is a scare tactic and a deliberately misleading press release. It is about whipping up the kind of thing you have not had much success with since you last tried to scare this community in respect of doing away with Christmas carols. Again, I urge people that this is absolutely wrong—
Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee, why don't you go back to the races? You are much better at the Cairns races than you are at child care. Thousands of families around this country were needlessly scared and made anxious about that whole vicious campaign. What I have been doing over the last number of weeks is travelling around Australia, listening to parents and families talking about—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not scaring anybody but putting out the lies that you are telling over there. Those parents are saying that the most important thing—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator, I would ask you to withdraw that reference to the opposition.

—Mr President, I withdraw. They are deliberately going around the country planting misinformation and misrepresenting the facts. In fact, Dr Kemp is so good at it he continues to put out press releases with the facts wrong. Either he is very thick or he intends to be deliberately wrong.

PARA.TAB: What parents say is most important for them is quality. They want to know when they leave their children that they are leaving them in a quality care process. They would like to know that when they leave their children in child care, they are leaving their children in a quality child-care approved centre. They like the accreditation process; they have actually approved it. The Coopers & Lybrand report says that very independently.

One of the interesting things is that the last time Senator McGauran was running this kind of mischievous campaign, he did declare on radio that he had not been to a child-care centre in a long time. But I suspect that is still the truth, senator. You would not know a good child-care centre from a crummy one. You probably do not even know your way to one.

This is an absolute scurrilous attack on the National Child Care Accreditation Council, which is doing no more than implementing the law passed in this place. To label it as you are a year after the events, senator, is only going to upset families and create anxiety.

If you want to know what the child-care centres are saying, do not just listen to the people talking to you, senator; listen to all the private centres and listen to the community based centres. They will tell you differently on behalf of the parents. Parents want quality. Parents want to have that assurance. Why don't you go and listen to them, instead of putting out this scurrilous muck that is only going to upset and agitate people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, does this press release from Senator McGauran suggest that the National Party's child-care policy actually supports a return to unregulated backyard centres with no monitoring of safe, secure standards for Australia's children?
—Mr President—

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 31 August, almost three weeks ago, the Senate unanimously passed a resolution calling on the Australian government to take urgent action to secure the release of Dr V.J. Flynn, an Australian academic who has been held in detention without trial for 15 months in India on coin smuggling charges, pending a proper resolution of this matter. In view of strong criticisms by friends of Dr Flynn of what they say is the inadequate response of the Australian consular service to his plight, what action has the minister taken to ensure that the human rights of this Australian citizen, which are claimed to have been disregarded by Australian authorities, are given the full protection that strong diplomatic representations could provide?

—I am not at all sure that the current very high profile media campaign being directed on this issue is really serving Dr Flynn's interests very well. I certainly have concerns—and I have had them for many months now—about his continued detention without trial under the relevant Indian legislation, particularly given his ongoing health problems. We share the concerns which have been articulated about many aspects of the handling of the case within the Indian system, particularly with regard to the delays in the High Court hearing of the case against his detention and some of the uncertainties and vagaries that have been involved on the criminal side of the equation.

PARA.TAB: But it is simply utterly untrue to say that I, or my department, or the Australian High Commission in New Delhi, have been sitting on our hands, somehow lacking interest in this matter. I, for a start, raised the issue with one of my Indian counterparts when I was there in May. Senator McMullan did so as well earlier this year. High Commission officers have met with Dr Flynn on more than two dozen occasions, on top of numerous and often very long telephone conversations with him and his legal representatives concerning his detention, as you would expect in a matter of this complexity.

The Australian High Commission has itself made over 10 representations—a number of them at very high level—to the Indian authorities concerning his medical condition and the conditions of his detention. The High Commission has also made to date over a dozen additional representations to the Indian government in connection with the legal case against him under the detention order and in the separate context of offences under the Customs Act.

There are extraordinarily complex legal issues involved here. For a start, there is the question associated with criminal proceedings under the Customs Act which were initiated only after a long delay, are very slow and which have not yet got to the stage of even committal for trial. But, at Dr Flynn's request—and this has not featured very largely in the media campaign or the public relations firm's accounts of what is going on—the High Commission has been asked directly not to intervene in any of the judicial proceedings under the Customs Act.

So far as the other proceeding, which is the present authority for his detention, that is under the Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act, which is a form of administrative detention and, as such, highly colourable in principle, one would have thought; although it is subject to procedures for judicial review applications and a number of things of that kind: we have supported his legal case under that act.

We were in fact on the verge of initiating a further legal action, just prior to the media campaign which started last week, which did involve an application for parole and which would have been followed by further application under section 11 of the relevant act for the revocation of the detention order. We have been asked now by Dr Flynn and his lawyers not to pursue that particular action. I am not quite sure why that is the case. One reason for not pursuing the parole action that has been bruited about in public statements recently is the suggestion that to proceed with the parole application would somehow jeopardise his situation because it would represent a kind of concession to the validity of the detention order.

That is all very well; except that Flynn's own lawyers made just such an application themselves under section 12 for temporary release or parole, which bid failed on 5 July. We were seeking ways, by taking our own legal advice to do so, in order to have another go at just that action which they themselves had taken and had failed. If they thought that was conceding the validity of the detention order then, why they have changed their minds now I am not quite sure.

I am being urged to make various kinds of high profile, arm flapping representations to the Indians about the validity of their various legal regimes under international conventions and so on. I am certainly happy to raise those issues, but I do really seriously question the judgment involved in doing so when careful, cautious, behind the scenes exercises of the kind on which we have been embarked are the way forward. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it more important to fuel the French nuclear tests with our uranium and so fulfil our business contracts or to place a priority on morality and, in doing so, support the vast majority of the people in Australia who are urging you to stop our uranium exports to France?

—We are not fuelling the French nuclear tests with our uranium. There is a small quantity of Australian uranium, representing about three per cent of the commercial power energy sources that are required, which goes into the civil side of the French system. That is subject to a bilateral safeguards arrangement. It is also subject, like similar arrangements of other nuclear weapon states, to a voluntary offer agreement which France has entered into and which enables the IAEA to verify that the designated nuclear material in France remains in civil use.

PARA.TAB: The whole safeguard system, which as I said yesterday has been absolutely crucial to the maintenance of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty regime since the 1960s, depends on the operations of those particular safeguards. If some ill-considered and misguided statements by French ministers have called into question the French commitment to those safeguard regimes, then the French have bought for themselves a much more serious problem than the one involving the supply of Australian uranium. What they have done is thrown into doubt the credibility of their commitment to a safeguards system which is applicable world wide and which is of fundamental importance, as I have just said, to the integrity of the nuclear non-proliferation system.

We have absolutely nothing to apologise for so far as the supply of Australian uranium is concerned. It is not just a matter of making a commercial return and not having anything to be concerned about so far as the use of that uranium for military purposes is concerned. It is more than that. As I tried to explain to Senator Margetts, I think it was, the other day, all of those countries around the world that possess either nuclear technology or nuclear raw materials have an obligation under the non-proliferation treaty, because of the balance of obligations that were struck in that treaty, to make available that material or that technology, as the case may be, for peaceful purposes.

That is the bargain that was struck in the 1960s to ensure that the then non-nuclear weapon states would not acquire nuclear weapons. They said, `We're prepared to go down that track provided we are guaranteed a supply of uranium or a supply of nuclear technology and provided we are not going to be prejudiced, inhibited or disadvantaged in any way.' Those other countries—the weapon states—accepted certain obligations to eventually eliminate their weapons and do a number of other things. Countries generally, including those in the position of Australia which possess this resource, were also obligated to follow a certain course.

That is why we are sticking to our guns on this. Not only do we think that there is no reason for doubt about where the uranium is actually going because the safeguards system does work, not only because we think the French are being extremely cynical in the way in which they are advancing this particular proposition because they know perfectly well, as I said yesterday, that they stand to benefit commercially if we do go down this track because of the cheaper availability of spot uranium at the moment, but we stand by our position because it is a principled position and because it goes to the heart of the credibility of the nuclear non-proliferation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I guess the answer to the first part of my supplementary question will be no. PARA.TAB: As to the specific point, France, as I said earlier, like the other nuclear weapons states, because of the specific arrangements which are applicable to the nuclear weapons states, has entered into what is known as a voluntary offer agreement which enables the IAEA to verify that designated nuclear material in France remains in civil use. PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Panizza this day, relating to taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: In taking note of that answer, Senator Evans supported the misconception, I believe, espoused by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that the superannuation guarantee is not regarded as a tax. I wonder whether he has confused the superannuation guarantee and the superannuation levy.

PARA.TAB: If he is talking about the superannuation levy he may have an argument. To work out which is regarded as a tax and which is not, apply the income tax test. If something is allowable against your earnings, then it is not regarded as a tax. If it is disallowed, it is defined as a tax. In the case of superannuation—it is added wages that an employer pays and sends off to a superannuation company—if the employer does not do that or there is a shortfall, then the superannuation guarantee comes in. That then becomes a tax and the employer cannot claim that as a tax deduction. You cannot have it both ways. I believe that whatever is taken off an employee and employer by law should be regarded as a tax.
The best I can do at this stage is quote from a letter from our Treasurer, Mr Willis, published in the Australian Financial Review. He says:
Employer contributions to superannuation funds under the Superannuation Guarantee are not included in taxation revenue figures—

SPEECH.PARA: even though they go straight to the tax department—
for Australia because the OECD defines taxation revenue to include only social security contributions which are paid to a government institution.
He goes on to say:

Contributions under the Superannuation Guarantee are paid to private sector superannuation funds where they provide investment capital from which retirement benefits to employees eventually arise. These contributions are not available for the Commonwealth Government to use for its own purposes and are therefore, appropriately—
that is in his view—
not defined by the OECD as taxation revenue.
He goes on to say:

The social security contribution schemes of other countries that you allude to are paid to government for the purposes of government providing social security benefits, on a pay as you go basis. They are no more than hypothecated tax, and are rightly treated as such by the OECD.

That is something I would like to question. The point is paying the levy to a private superannuation fund is simply like the government contracting out to the private sector, and the private sector generally does it better—in fact, I believe it does it better all the time.

PARA.TAB: So when this government, or any government, decides by law to take money away from an employer or an employee and put it in a private institution to do a job that the government eventually has to do—that is, provide pensions—then, by providing superannuation instead of a pension, that should be regarded as a tax. When you properly lump that together, you will find that we rank about the middle of OECD countries, no matter what sort of excuses the government makes in comparing us with any of those other OECD countries. That is where we finish up because that money is compulsorily taken from employers and employees and goes to those institutions. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to French nuclear testing in the South Pacific region and the export of uranium to France.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by pointing out that President Chirac has said that Australian uranium finishes up in French nuclear bombs. He asked, `If you are so concerned about our nuclear weapons tests, why do you provide us with uranium that finishes up in our bombs?'

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) has said that President Chirac is a liar. Actually, he said that he was misinformed but, essentially, he implied that President Chirac told an untruth. I believe that, on all the evidence, President Chirac is telling the truth.

Senator Evans is relying on a piece of paper, the NPT, when he knows very little about the actual administration of the NPT. For instance, as we will show later in the week when we get some more evidence to support this, France, as a nuclear weapons state, has a civil program which technically comes under the NPT and the International Atomic Energy Agency inspection process, but at the same time has a nuclear weapons program which is excluded from the NPT and the IAEA inspections.

We will produce evidence later in the week which will show that due to that conflict of activity within the same facility—that is, using low enrichment uranium for the civil program and high enrichment uranium for the military program—the IAEA inspectors are excluded from carrying out comprehensive inspections. It is quite conceivable, even theoretically, that under the NPT and the IAEA inspections, Australian uranium can find its way into nuclear weapons.

I do not want Senator Evans trying to confuse the issue by saying that we are trying to identify uranium atom for atom. We are well aware of the fact that when a batch of uranium goes in for enrichment, it may be 10 per cent uranium from Australia and 90 per cent from somewhere else. When it comes out, 10 per cent might go into civil programs. But based on the evidence we put before the Senate as long ago as 1989, we are arguing that after that process, uranium scraps from Australia, clearly labelled as such, were swapped with highly enriched uranium which went into the military program.

We have produced direct evidence to this Senate and I called on Senator Evans to pick up on that. Is he saying that the evidence we produced as long ago as 1989 was wrong? The evidence was well corroborated and well authenticated that at that stage Australian uranium was finding its way into the French military program.

I am well aware that there are clauses in the NPT which, confusingly, require nuclear states, states with nuclear technology and nuclear facilities, to share those with states which do not possess that. Many of us in the anti-nuclear movement for decades have been pointing out the stupidity of having both an exploitative and expansive set of clauses built into a facility which should be actually controlling an activity. There is a conflict of interest in there. I wonder whether, in the recent renegotiation of the NPT, the Australian government sought to remove those clauses which so confuse the issue.

I point out again that what the minister is saying is that he is not believing President Chirac, who has made a clear statement; he is believing the implementation of a signature on a piece of paper. I do not think that is justified. I think that Australia should desist from exporting its uranium to France, where it does find its way into French nuclear weapons. That is what concerns the majority of Australian people, and they want this government to stop that export.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

I refer to Statutory Rules 1995 No 55 being the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicle Standards) Regulations which are presently before the Committee. The proposed Regulations provide a set of standards, uniform throughout Australia, for the construction and performance of heavy motor vehicles and trailers.

Proposed Regulation 7 provides that the Minister may exempt a specified vehicle from a requirement of the Heavy Vehicle Standards on being satisfied after applying a number of criteria. PARA.EMPHASIS: Statement to the Senate on scrutiny by the Committee of regulations implementing a national uniform legislative scheme

SPEECH.PARA: Among the instruments of delegated legislation scrutinised by the Committee to ensure compliance with personal rights and parliamentary propriety are instruments made as part of intergovernmental schemes, including those intended to implement national uniform legislation in a particular area.

Such legislation presents special challenges for legislative scrutiny committees. These challenges were recognised in the key Report by the Administrative Review Council on Rule Making by Commonwealth Agencies, in the establishment by the Western Australian Parliament of the Standing Committee on Uniform Legislation and Intergovernmental Agreements Committee and in the circulation earlier this year by the Chairs of scrutiny of legislation committees throughout Australia of a discussion paper on Scrutiny of National Scheme Legislation.

Recently the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances scrutinised regulations which were made as part of such a uniform national scheme. The scheme in question was given effect at the Commonwealth level by the National Road Transport Commission Act 1991, which included as a schedule an agreement between the Commonwealth, all States and the Australian Capital Territory. The agreement recited that there should be improvements to road safety, efficiency and administrative costs; and that this necessitates uniform or consistent legislation throughout Australia, to be achieved by a cooperative legislative scheme. The agreement further recited that the essential element of the scheme was that the Commonwealth would make law for the ACT which would be the model for legislation by the States and Northern Territory, which in turn would enact laws consistent with the model. The agreement also established a Ministerial Council, the approval of which was necessary before the model law could be made. The approval of the Ministerial Council is also necessary for the amendment of the model law.

The first Commonwealth legislation as part of the scheme was the Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Act 1993, which expressly provided that it forms part of the national scheme envisaged by the National Road Transport Commission Act. It further provided that its purpose was to empower the making of laws for the Australian Capital Territory which are intended to be adopted by the States and the Northern Territory. The Act did not itself include any substantive provisions dealing with vehicles or traffic, instead providing that regulations may be made in respect of these matters. It was these regulations which are the legislative basis of the scheme as it affects users and which came before the Committee in the same way as other Commonwealth regulations.

The first module of the uniform scheme included the Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicle Standards) Regulations and the Road Transport Reform (Oversize and Overmass Vehicles) Regulations. The heavy vehicle regulations include seven pages of what might be termed substantive legislation and one hundred pages of technical engineering standards. The oversize and overmass vehicles regulations include nine pages of substantive legislation and forty seven pages of engineering standards. Both sets of regulations apply to the Australian Capital Territory and the Jervis Bay Territory only, but each expressly provides that their purpose is to provide a set of standards uniform or consistent throughout Australia. Both Explanatory Statements advise that the regulations will be incorporated into the law of each of the States and the Northern Territory.

The Committee scrutinised these regulations in the usual way and found that several provisions were cause for concern. The most important of these were provisions under which vehicles may be exempted from the prescribed standards. Such exemptions, which may apply to individual vehicles, could have commercial benefit for operators. There appeared to be, however, no provision for independent review of decisions adverse to vehicle owners or operators. The Committee normally would consider that review of administrative discretions which may confer a commercial advantage is essential. In addition, one of the sets of regulations provided for strict liability offences, for which the Committee usually seeks an explanation. The Committee raised these matters formally with the Minister.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport, the Hon Neil O'Keefe MP, responded to the Committee's concerns on 6 June 1995, attaching detailed advice from the National Road Transport Commission. The Committee considered the reply and requested further advice on the issues of concern. The Parliamentary Secretary replied on 29 August 1995, advising that appropriate review provisions would be included in proposed new regulations to replace the present provisions and that the strict liability provisions would be amended to meet the Committee's concerns. The proposed amendments would be submitted expeditiously to the Ministerial Council. In the meantime, the present regulations would not be commenced until the Ministerial Council agreed to the new regulations. The Parliamentary Secretary also arranged for additional material from the National Road Transport Commission to be sent to the Committee.

Normally the Committee would regard this reply as entirely satisfactory and the Committee congratulates the Parliamentary Secretary on his commitment to ensuring that delegated legislation provides the highest possible safeguards for personal rights. In this case, however, the Committee wrote again to Mr O'Keefe. The reason for this is that while the Committee accepts undertakings from Ministers, who are answerable in Parliament for their actions, the Ministerial Council, which under the uniform national scheme must approve the amendments, is not directly answerable in this way. The Committee therefore asked the Parliamentary Secretary if he could arrange for the Minister for Transport to give similar assurances, both sets of regulations providing for commencement upon a date notified in the Gazette by the Commonwealth Minister. The Committee also requested a report in three months on progress with the new regulations. In addition, the Committee wrote to the Chairs of State and Territory legislative scrutiny Committees describing its actions in this matter.

The Parliamentary Secretary then replied to the Committee, confirming that he had the authority to act on behalf of the Minister in this matter and that neither set of regulations would commence before the Ministerial Council agreed to the replacement regulations. The Committee accepted this reply but agreed to keep the matter under review, the present sets of regulations being only the first module of a number of successive modules to implement the entire national scheme.

I have reported to the Senate in some detail on this matter because of the unusual procedures mandated by the national uniform legislative scheme under which these regulations were made. These procedures, required by an agreement between the executives of the Commonwealth, States and mainland Territories, in effect oblige the Commonwealth to make delegated legislation under a Commonwealth Act only with the approval of a Ministerial Council and not to amend that legislation without similar approval. The Committee agreed that the agreement would not constrain its usual scrutiny of the regulations and, with the helpful cooperation of the Parliamentary Secretary, Neil O'Keefe, I am pleased to report to the Senate that undertakings have been given in respect of the regulations which ensure that the high standards of the Committee are maintained.

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 29 June 1995, about the Radiocommunications (Multipoint Distribution Station Licences—Regional Licences) Guidelines No. 1 of 1995 (the Guidelines). You asked how the words ". . . in the opinion of the SMA, may be affected by the operation of an MDS or other transmitter. . . ", which appear in Guideline 18, could be construed as anything other than a discretion.

In its letter of 1 June 1995, the Committee sought information on whether the exercise of the discretions, conferred on the Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) in Guidelines 17 and 18, are subject to an independent review on the merits. In my reply of 22 June 1995, I advised that decisions made under these Guidelines were reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I also indicated that the SMA considers that it does not exercise discretions under the Guidelines. This means that the SMA does not exercise discretionary powers under the Guidelines; such powers are exercised under the Radiocommunications Act 1992 (the Act).

The SMA advises that the formation of an opinion such as that required by Guideline 18 is, generally speaking, of no import or effect if it is not coupled with some further action such as the exercise of a power, be it statutory or executive. It is for this reason that review provisions are directed at the exercise of statutory powers, rather than specifically at the formation of the state of mind that is to precede the exercise of powers.

I understand that the SMA drew the distinction in this case so as to make clear to the Committee the reasons why the Guidelines did not themselves contain the relevant review provisions. In other words, the SMA was seeking to draw the Committee's attention to the fact that, in the case of the licences that are the subject of the Guidelines, the criteria for the exercise of the powers in sections 107(l)(g) and 111 of the Act are contained in Guideline 17, whilst the relevant powers are contained in the sections themselves. This is a somewhat unusual circumstance but is one dictated by the form of the Act itself, as section 112 of the Act provides for statutory criteria to be imposed by means of disallowable instrument, in this case, the Guidelines.

The SMA advises that, although it is conceivable that in some circumstances the formation of the opinion without a corresponding exercise of power could be of some import or have an effect, such circumstances would be relatively rare. For example, if licensees were to avail themselves of the statutory conciliation process to deal with alleged interference between services, the SMA could be asked to provide an opinion on whether one service might interfere with another. That opinion could then be of some importance in the conciliation process and directly or indirectly affect the outcome.

As I advised earlier, the exercise of the powers of the SMA to impose and vary licence conditions under sections 107(l)(g) and 111 of the Act is reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is through this mechanism that the question of whether the statutory criteria for the exercise of those powers have been met, may also be reviewed. I trust that this explanation meets the Committee's concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The dire need for federal government and mining industry intervention to halt the death of wildlife, risk to groundwater and destruction of native vegetation caused by the toxic tailings dams of the gold mining industry.

I thank my colleagues for supporting the motion in a spirit of bipartisanship. Today I am calling for the federal government to act with urgency on the enormous environmental problems associated with goldmine tailings dams—also known as impoundment areas, concentrator residue impoundment areas or slime dumps—in Australia. There are at least 164 such goldmine tailings dams in Australia and a great proportion of them do not fulfil the federal government's own statement of best practice environmental management in mining projects. This is an inadequacy which can and does have enormous ecological consequences for wildlife, ground water, vegetation and human health in the area of the tails dam.

PARA.TAB: The 1.5 square kilometre tailings dam of North Ltd's Parkes goldmine in New South Wales, shown on the 60 Minutes report Dam of death on Sunday night, is only one example. At this tailings dam up to 2,000 protected native birds—swans, ducks, cormorants—were poisoned by the highly toxic cyanide gas, which is produced by an unstable tailings dam, which the birds ingested.

The birds, being nomadic, tried to land in the water of the tailings dump, water that undoubtedly looked to all intents and purposes like habitat, comprising as it does a surface area of open water and wet mud, islands and remnant and regrowth vegetation. Cyanide levels in this dam were measured at 525 parts per million, despite company assurances that normal levels were 50 parts per million and never exceeded 300 parts per million. A dose of 100 to 200 milligrams of cyanide is lethal to humans.

Cyanide, also known as hydrocyanic acid or prussic acid, is most commonly recognised as the gas used for human execution in gas chambers. It is a fast acting poison and caustic agent that prevents animal cells from being able to absorb oxygen by inhibition of the enzymes that reduce oxidised cytochrome in cells. Once an animal—whether human, bird or otherwise—ingests cyanide gas, dizziness, nausea and finally loss of consciousness follow. Death—usually painful—occurs within minutes after contact with the gas.

The Lake Cowal goldmine project also proposed by North Ltd and featured in the 60 Minutes report on Sunday might is 100 kilometres south of the Parkes mine. This project, currently under environmental impact assessment, is proposing to build not one but four tailing dams, covering a total of 2.4 square kilometres, on the edge of one of the most internationally significant wetlands and bird habitats in Australia.

Windara mine near Laverton was the site of the death of 60,000 budgerigars killed by cyanide gas from the mine tailing in 1985. In the goldfields, toxicity problems are not monitored and could be a source of similar environmental catastrophe in the future if the problem is not addressed by this government immediately. International examples include the Ok Tedi case of the BHP goldmine on the Fly River, which is well known, and the Omai goldmine in Guyana, which on Saturday 19 August experienced a tailings dam collapse where huge amounts of cyanide and copper were leached into the environment.

More accurately, the people of Omai experienced the tailings collapse. An estimated 90,000 cubic metres of cyanide loaded water from the tailings washed into the river per hour and then into the Essequibo River on which the people of Omai rely for drinking. The leakage was let run unchecked by the company for five days before it was sealed, by which time four million cubic metres of tailings water was in the river. Immediately, the World Health Organisation's health and environment adviser was called and warned residents along the river to stop using the water for cooking or drinking. Aquatic life along the Omai and Essequibo rivers was described by the adviser as being completely destroyed.

In addition to the cyanide problems involved in negligently constructed tailing structures, mine tailings dams are highly saline. One of the major discrepancies between the government's current best practice guidelines for tailings dams and the design of tailings dams in the field is the issue of the use of lining membranes on the perimeters of the dam. The great proportion of currently operative and proposed tailings structures are not lined. This problem was highlighted in a keynote speech to the Third International Conference on Environmental Issues and Waste Management in Energy and Mineral Production in Perth in August 1994.

As a result of being unlined, both the highly toxic cyanide compounds and the salt from the tails water soak through the floor of the dam and into the watertable. The ramifications of this effect are threefold. Firstly, salinity in ground water limits the possible uptake of water by vegetation on the perimeter and surrounds of the dam. It is reduced in the roots of plants, particularly tall eucalypts, because the salt concentration gradient between the soil and the plant root that is necessary for osmosis to continue is unbalanced or reversed in the presence of this highly saline soil and the osmosis stops. Often plant root cell membrane damage results from causing water to move out of the plant through the roots, and the plant dies and dries out. This occurs even in the salt tolerant plants found in the goldfields, and eucalypts can die within days of their roots coming into contact with the high concentration of salinity from leaked tails water.

Secondly, the cyanide contained in tails water absorbed by the soil pollutes ground water that may be accessed by nearby towns and mining camps, having potentially fatal effects. Thirdly, the leakage of cyanide in goldmining areas can have an economic effect, in that it chemically reacts with any gold in the soil and makes it unable to be extracted. If successfully managed, a tailings impoundment can be a relatively minor hazard. It is the instability of tailings dams that causes the leakage of lethal cyanide gas and the lack of proper containment facilities that creates the dangers of salinity and cyanide filtration into the soil.

An awareness of these problems is outlined in the government's own statement on best practice, yet these practices are almost unanimously shirked by proponents of the mining industry. Although the mining industry is at present spending a good amount of their budgets on mine revegetation, little is being spent on addressing the issues of lifetime tailing stability, acid waste drainage, lateral and vertical leakage of contaminated water, and the dangers to fauna and birds that use the area as habitat.

The North Ltd Lake Cowal proposal is only one example of the arbitrary lack of concern seemingly reflected by the mining industry with regard to the ecological dangers of goldmine effluent. Even proposing to build a tailings structure on a wetland such as Lake Cowal indicates this in stark relief. The issues associated with tailings dams in Australia are of such environmental significance that the Greens (WA) and their supporters feel a national inquiry into goldmine tails structures is necessary and will be pursuing avenues to begin this process immediately.
