TALK.START.PARA: —I think this issue has arisen because of the segment on the 60 Minutes program on the Nine Network on Sunday night which focused on a significant kill of native birds in a tailings dam at the Northparkes mine in central western New South Wales. That mine is operated by North Ltd, a major Australian mining company. I too am very concerned about the contents and the images on the 60 Minutes program and about the company's admission that about 2,000 birds have been killed in the company's tailings dam.

PARA.TAB: The apparent lack of proper care for the environment at the Northparkes mine does give me cause for concern about the company's proposal to develop a new mine at Lake Cowal, which is some 150 kilometres south of the existing Northparkes mine. Lake Cowal is an important wetland, as it is a significant drought refuge when other parts of the state are dry. It is utilised by a large number of water birds. Many species of water birds actually breed at Lake Cowal. The lake also supports a commercial fishing industry when the lake is full. Lake Cowal is listed in the directory of important wetlands in Australia. It is not a listed Ramsar site.

The government would be particularly concerned about the possible introduction of cyanide and other compounds into the water table or the surface waters of Lake Cowal. I understand that the Lake Cowal mining proposal would involve the use of tailings dams and cyanide, which would obviously clearly have the potential for damage. I understand from officers in my own department that there have been other significant kills of native birds from cyanide poisoning in tailings dams in other parts of Australia. Obviously, there are a lot of tailings dams associated with the goldmining industry in this country. In fact, some 100 tailings dams exist here. I understand that there have been native bird kills in the goldfields of Kalgoorlie and also in other goldmining areas as well.

As I have been informed, it is a relatively simple management procedure to prevent native bird deaths from cyanide in tailings dams by minimising the amount of water that is stored in tailings dams and minimising the concentration of free cyanide in the tailings dams to a level of less than 50 parts per million, which is not harmful to wildlife. Given the cost of cyanide, I would also assume that mine managers would be keen to recycle and reuse as much of this cyanide as possible. Two relatively simple procedures—bird deaths on tailings dams and a risk of bird kills—could obviously be significantly reduced. I hope that those with responsibility for mine management would take account of those measures and others that might be able to be utilised to ensure that we do not face the similar situation that occurred at Northparkes.

It would appear from the content of the 60 Minutes television program that these basic procedures were not implemented at Northparkes and, as a consequence, these bird deaths occurred. I am concerned that the industry—which naturally wants to be seen as environmentally responsible and wants to improve what I think is a relatively poor public image—is again being seen to be not doing the right thing, and I must say that that is disappointing.

The issues of ground water and Australia's goldmining industry are of great significance not only to those with an environmental consciousness but also to the community in general. I understand that with good design, construction, management and monitoring, tailings dams should not be a source of major ground water contamination in this country. Again, it is in the best interests of all responsible mine managers to ensure that their tailings dams are well designed, well constructed and well managed so that the industry does not leave a legacy of ground water contamination for future generations.

Some native vegetation is destroyed by the construction of tailings dams and other infrastructure that is associated with mines, such as roads, workshops, processing plants and so forth. However, it is the responsibility of the Australian mining industry to satisfactorily rehabilitate all areas disturbed by its activities. We need to acknowledge that the Australian mining industry—in particular, the goldmining sector—is important to our economy, but mining does have an environmental impact. It is a matter for the industry and the community to work together to ensure that we have a sustainable industry that is environmentally responsible.

In order to encourage the mining industry to improve its environmental performance, my department recently entered into a partnership with the Australian mining industry to encourage best practice environmental management in mining. Recently, I launched nine booklets and a video, and they have been well received by the industry and government and community groups not only in Australia but also overseas. It is unfortunate that we are debating an issue which should not have arisen and which can only harm the industry's reputation and have tragic consequences because of the wildlife that is killed.

I make the point that this fundamentally is a responsibility of state governments. I have received some preliminary information from the office of the New South Wales Minister for Mineral Resources about the issue canvassed on the 60 Minutes program, and I will be writing to my counterpart in the New South Wales government to seek further details on this incident.

While I am very concerned about the incident—which I assume is the reason for this motion being moved—and about a number of other reports of bird deaths from tailings dams, I cannot agree with the words in Senator Chamarette's motion, which talks about, `The dire need for federal government and mining industry intervention'. I propose an amendment to the motion, which I hope will be acceptable to Senator Chamarette and other senators in the chamber—but time will tell. My proposed amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Federal and State Governments to continue to work together with the mining industry to avoid the death of wildlife, risk to groundwater and destruction of native vegetation caused by the toxic tailings dams of the gold mining industry.
I hope that, in the spirit in which I will move that amendment, it will find broad acceptance in the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the urgency motion proposed by Senator Chamarette and to endorse a number of remarks made by both senators who have spoken on this motion. Like Senator Faulkner, I have some concerns about the way Senator Chamarette's motion is worded. Again like Senator Faulkner, I too have a proposal to better tailor the motion to what I think the reality of the position is. However, the coalition strongly supports the sentiments behind the motion and the concern that Senator Chamarette has expressed about the effect that toxic tailings dams can have on wildlife, ground water and vegetation.

PARA.TAB: The motion, as I said, could probably be better worded. It does not mention the responsibilities of state government, which, as Senator Faulkner said, does have the prime responsibility in this area, and it does not mention the responsibility that individual companies have to observe the law and the regulations under which they are established. So, as I have mentioned, I have slightly reworded the motion and I will seek to move an amendment at the end of my remarks.

Let me make it clear that the Australian community expects companies to observe the highest possible standards to protect our environment. Clearly, what we had at Northparkes mine was an environmental stuff-up of considerable magnitude. It should be recalled that the establishment of Northparkes mine came after an EIS, an environmental impact study. Under current state acts of parliament, the establishment of mines comes only after the appropriate EIS.

The EIS, which is conducted prior to the establishment of a goldmine, typically sets out the conditions under which the goldmine will operate. The EIS stipulated, among other things, I understand, that the tailings dam would not contain toxic levels of cyanide. Unfortunately, it is now very clear that there was clearly a weakness in the company's environmental management system which led to toxic concentrations of cyanide in the tailings dam, the results of which were spelt out in the 60 Minutes program.

However, it is also worth noting that the company has taken, I understand, rapid remedial action. Among other things, it has written to the Minerals Council of Australia and indicated that it has changed the type of ore being processed to reduce the cyanide usage. It has purchased a hovercraft to commence daily monitoring of the dam and to rescue and deter birds from the dam. It has purchased a propane gas gun to deter birds and has investigated ways to reduce the cyanide levels in the dam quicker than achieved through the cyanide neutralisation plant. It is clear, as one would expect, that the company has moved to rectify the situation, which should never have occurred.

As I said, the incident at Northparkes mine was in breach of the agreement under which the mine operates. It may seem harsh, but in many ways, I suspect, you could say the company deserved to cop it—and cop it, it did. It is also worth recording that the company denies that it was involved in a cover-up of the situation which developed at the mine.

Mining companies themselves have a prime responsibility to ensure that their own activities do not pollute the environment and, among other things, pose the types of risks that are set out in the motion. Apparently, at Northparkes mine in New South Wales, the cyanide content of the tailings dams reached high levels which resulted in some 2,000 bird deaths. Birds such as teals, ducks and seagulls alight on the tailings dams and, on ingesting the cyanide-rich water, have died.

The cyanide increase in the tailings dams apparently resulted from mining lower grade ores. The company says that, when it became aware of the problem, it stopped the process and put neutralisers in the dam to prevent more deaths. I am pleased to hear that the company has apologised for the deaths. The managing director, Mr Swan, has said that the company takes the issue very seriously and very much regrets the deaths.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do the birds say about the apology?

—The company has stated—and I do not know whether Senator Coulter will be able to add more to this—that none of the deaths were of threatened or endangered species. But none of this is to offer any excuse. There is no doubt that companies have to be eternally vigilant in these areas and the community expects no less. Even companies which believe they meet the higher standards cannot rest on their laurels.

PARA.TAB: I was interested when reading the press cuttings relating to this event that Northparkes copper mine was named as a winner of the 1994 award for environmental excellence in New South Wales and was presented with such an award. I think it demonstrates the fact that even companies that believe they have taken a lead in this area and have set high standards simply cannot rest on their laurels. Clearly, we can assume that is what happened with the resulting deaths of those birds.

The issue was also raised by a number of other speakers that there have been deaths of birds at other tailings dams. I think Senator Faulkner drew the attention of the Senate to the fact that cyanide in tailings water at goldmines located near wetlands can be a threat to migratory birds. Desert wildlife and bird life generally remain close to permanent water supplies but, in times of drought or bushfires, the birds sometimes have to find other supplies of water and feed, otherwise they would die through lack of water or starvation. Therefore, they are sometimes attracted to tailings dams. If they go to tailings dams which are toxic, death can result as well.

I understand that previous deaths have been recorded at the Granites, Tanami and Warrego mines in the Northern Territory, so it is not a problem which is confined entirely to this particular site. It is an issue which mining companies have to effectively address. The industry itself has to make sure that it works with state governments and other responsible people to ensure that deaths of this type are minimised, if not entirely eradicated. I am pleased to hear that the Minerals Council is looking at a number of ways in which it can better address the question of cyanide and its effect on wildlife management.

As I said, there is an issue which Senator Chamarette has brought to the attention of the Senate. I think companies these days that do not observe high environmental standards do pay a community price, and that price has been paid by Northparkes mine. I think all of us would agree that these things must be avoided in the future and that companies themselves have to be eternally vigilant in this regard. I now foreshadow the amendment I will move to Senator Chamarette's motion. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: the vital need for Governments, mining companies and the mining industry to ensure that tailings dams of the gold mining industry do not lead to the death of wildlife, pollute ground water and unnecessarily destroy vegetation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several issues that come out of this matter of the death of birds, not only at this particular site in New South Wales, but, as Senator Chamarette has pointed out, in a number of other sites around the world. Of course, it impacts on human health as well in Guyana and a number of other places. The level which was mentioned in the 60 Minutes program, which I think both Senator Chamarette and Senator Faulkner mentioned, of 520 parts per million of course would be low compared with the original level in the water. Cyanide is one of those things that classically are quite easily oxidised and almost certainly the levels would have been much higher than that had they been mentioned earlier.

PARA.TAB: I think there are a couple of things that come out of this matter, though. The first one is that, no matter how well you do EISs, when companies do EISs and present them, there is no guarantee whatsoever that the information contained in those EISs is even reliable, let alone that the imposition of standards through the EIS and assessment process will in fact be observed. I think in this case we have probably seen a company that has been very slick with its advertising, has in fact won some awards and got away with it. Unfortunately for it, of course, it has got caught out and I think the 60 Minutes program showed that quite nicely.

So I make a plea; it is a plea that has been made often enough in the past. Environmental impact statements need to be made independently of the proposers of projects, they need to be independently assessed, and there needs to be independent monitoring, not monitoring by the companies of their own operations. I think that comes clearly out of all these cases of pollution of tailings dams with cyanide and the death of birds and the other environmental impacts that we have seen.

The main point I wanted to pick up this afternoon was touched on incorrectly, briefly by Senator Faulkner when he talked about the sustainability of mining. Of course, when we are mining minerals, we are in fact carrying out an unsustainable activity, by definition. These are non-renewable resources, and I think it is very interesting that we are having this debate today, the day after we saw the World Bank figures which showed that Australia, on a per capita basis, is the richest country in the world.

Looking at lunch time at that 60 Minutes program, I noted that the company was saying that the gold from its existing mine and its proposed new mine at Lake Cowal would net $250 million and $150 million, respectively. The point I want to make, the point I want to stress, is that those are not real figures. Those are the capital values of the gold whether it is in the ground or whether it is taken out of the ground. There is no value whatsoever in mining that gold. That gold will still be there in 10 years, in 20 years, in 100 years time if our children or our descendants want eventually to mine it.

I asked Senator Gareth Evans an important question yesterday, and in response he gave me this booklet `National Balance Sheets of Australia' which shows that the Australian Bureau of Statistics had attempted, quite incorrectly, to make some assessment of the capital value of Australia's assets. The whole point about this is that we should be keeping different accounts. What we have seen in this case is massive pollution, massive environmental damage in an area which could go on producing benefits for generations of native animals, of native plants, of Australians for thousands and thousands of years, measured against the immediate exploitation of a non-renewable resource which, if the accounting was done properly, would simply show that we had shifted $250 million out of our bank balance as a resource in the ground into cash flow.

When one looks at the accounting done properly, the accounting done as every business in this country would do its accounting, namely, keeping a capital account and a cash flow account, one can readily see that in this particular case we have the exploitation of a non-renewable resource for very, very little value whatsoever—actually, the value added to the gold in extracting it, not the value of the mineral in the ground, and at the expense of enormous environmental damage.

When we look at the accounting done in that proper way, we see that we should not be engaging in these mining operations. So we support the motion. We support it for perhaps stronger reasons than have been adduced so far and we strongly recommend that, coming out of this whole exercise, the EIS process be revisited.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is an amendment that has been workshopped in the most iterative process around the chamber, but I think we have broad consensus for it. I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "urgency:", substitute "The need for governments to work together with mining companies and the mining industry to avoid the death of wildlife, risk to ground water and destruction of native vegetation caused by the toxic tailings dams of the gold mining industry".

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few brief words to say about this matter. I support the amendment but I also have some concern not only about the mining industry but also some other industries as well. I think this particular case demonstrates how some people in this industry do not follow the rules. North Broken Hill, I think, are a classic example. From my point of view, it not only demonstrates their lack of concern for the environment; it is a bit like their effort in terms of industrial relations. They recently were caught out cutting down National Estate forest in Tasmania—and it would not be for the first time either.

PARA.TAB: I think that the companies do know the rules of the game and the government, or governments—really, this is a responsibility of state governments—set down rules for environmental purposes and they ought to be followed. Even if the 60 Minutes program was only half right—probably it was only half right—it gives cause for concern about the fact that this company allowed the wildlife, in this case birds, to continue to die without really following it up to any great degree. I think that is a sad reflection on the industry, which is a very important industry to this country. We have to get from our industries more responsibility in environmental matters. Whether or not it is the correct thing to do to try to lay the blame on the federal government or at least to say that the federal government ought to do something about it, we have to have a wider look at it.

It was not that long ago that there was an environmental issue raised on Groote Eylandt in respect of BHP. In the whistleblowers committee a number of submissions were made on environmental matters. That raised a serious concern about how companies operate. Effectively, companies are given a very significant right in this country which allows them to either mine or harvest certain natural resources and it is about time that they followed up that right that is given to them by giving some respect to the environment and demonstrating that respect.

Of course, there are some companies, probably the majority, that clearly do that. They do act in a proper and appropriate way. But there are those others, such as the one I have mentioned, that would seemingly not do that. I think it is very unfortunate that a particular company, one of the largest resource companies operating in Australia, would choose to be so defiant or would choose to act in such an improper way that it would lead to a motion being moved in this place about the risks to wildlife, ground water or about the destruction of native vegetation.

It is time something was done about it. We do have to bring about greater responsibility. I do not know that any inquiry Senator Chamarette is proposing would achieve that. I think, as Senator Faulkner outlined, it is the responsibility of state governments. I think there is a role for both governments to try to ensure greater adherence to environmental laws and to the requirements in terms and conditions of leases that are set down. I hope that as a result of the program shown and others there may be a greater effort to work towards that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute to this debate because I share with Senator Chamarette two things. The first is that we both have the privilege of living in Western Australia, which is a state that has in many respects been built on the back of a very significant gold industry. The second thing I share with Senator Chamarette is a very serious and long-term interest in ensuring that our environment is protected from degradation and spoil in the course of economic development. I have always been committed to that and believe that most of the Australian society demands a very sensible balance between economic development and protection of the environment, unlike Senator Coulter, who has now left the chamber but who believes that goldmining is an unsustainable activity.

PARA.TAB: In what could only be described as fairies at the bottom of the garden type economics, Senator Coulter said that gold is worth the same in the ground as it is out of the ground. The reality is that you actually have to go through the process of getting the gold out of the ground to make it worth anything. In many parts of Australia and through generations of Australia's history, the balance between extracting gold from the ground and the price you get for gold is one of the crucial determinants in Australia's national financial success.

I had the pleasure over the Christmas-New Year period of 1994-95 of reading a book my dad gave me for Christmas, that being the most recently updated book by Geoffrey Blainey entitled The Rush That Never Ended, which is a history of Australian mining with a specific reference to gold. From just flipping through it in the minutes I was waiting to make my contribution to the debate, I picked out a few paragraphs from Geoffrey Blainey's 1963 introduction to that history that I think should be placed on the record and placed in stark contrast to Senator Coulter's contribution that mining is unsustainable. Mr Blainey says in this introduction:

Out of the ground came wealth that created new industries. Humble silver and copper companies so prospered that they founded Australia's heavy chemical industry and one of the world's large iron and steel industries; they made paper and fertilisers and paints and built aircraft and ships. Wealth from Australian rocks created financial dynasties in London and Melbourne, and a fortune from Queensland gold was indispensable in finding Britain's rich oilfields in the Middle East.

Australian prospectors found or pioneered new mining fields from the Rand and Rhodesia to New Zealand and the Klondike. Australian mining investors opened Malayan tinlands and New Guinea and Fiji goldfields, and there is hardly a mining field that has not used Australian innovations in metallurgy.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect Senator Coulter would not have wanted some of those important contributions to the world economy from Australia's goldmining and mining industries to have occurred anyway. He probably would not want a heavy chemicals industry or, indeed, oil exploration in the Middle East. The reality in world history is that Australia has been a leader in mining. Mining technology that has been founded, created and innovated in Australia's goldmining industry has been exported to the rest of the world.

PARA.TAB: One of the silver linings to the cloud of North Ltd's Northparkes mine is that where you do have a catastrophe—that is the only word that can be used to describe the loss of so many thousands of native birds and the risks to other important parts of our native vegetation—it is ensured through this sort of focus, and I congratulate Senator Chamarette quite sincerely on raising the matter in the Senate, that public awareness is raised. Also, there is an increase in the pressure on those who do seek to exploit Australia's mineral resources to do so in a very responsible way.

The other thing the Australian mining industry has been able to export to the rest of the world is the technology the minister was talking about earlier—the engineering expertise to ensure that, when you build things like tailings dams and when you do things like creating all sorts of mines, you have the technology and the engineering expertise in the environmental sciences, which are flourishing in Australia. You build up an enormous store of knowledge and information that is an exportable commodity. Australia's mining engineers and environmental scientists are now winning enormous amounts of work all across the world.

There is another reason I support the now entirely agreed set of words. It is important that the mining companies themselves—I think Senator Murphy made this point very well—have a very strong sense of responsibility. I am sure they do. I do not think North Ltd would have set out at the EIS stage of the mining operation or at the feasibility stage, or at any stage of the development of this mine, to have a tailings dam that would have the environmental consequences that have very unfortunately occurred during the past few months. I am sure they earnestly sought to ensure that such devastation did not occur. I am quite sure that with their proposed dam at Lake Cowal their good intentions will also be there. Good intentions are simply not enough when you are dealing with sensitive environmental matters. There is no doubt that in a wetlands situation the potential for environmental damage is very high.

It is most important that the governments of Australia participate. In that I refer to all levels of government because I know that in my home state of Western Australia local government, particularly in the Kalgoorlie area, does have a very specific interest in environmental matters relating to mining and exploration developments. The mining companies these days do have a number of matters they need to take into account. I think the market is very well informed about the potential financial impact on mining companies of these sorts of environmental disasters.

In my research for this debate today, I came across a press clipping from 24 August. It related to an enormous cyanide spill in Guyana in southern America. Something like 1.25 million cubic litres of cyanide spilled into the Essequibo River. That created an enormous threat to not only the wildlife, the fish and the other life in and around that river, but also the population of something like 18,000 people who live on and around that river and who rely on that river not only for drinking water but also for the sustenance of their farms and animals.

The share price of the US and Canadian based companies that were the major shareholders in that mine plummeted by 24 per cent on the first day of trading after that mining incident took place. That shows the market is aware that when a company is involved in an environmental disaster it will be required to invest enormous sums of money in either a clean up or in future activities to ensure that such things do not happen again, that that has a massive impact on the company's financial environment. There is an enormous financial responsibility on companies to be responsible to the environment.

Governments do have an important role. State governments have the prime role in these environmental impact statements. The federal government, as the minister has said, has played a constructive role, and I congratulate the minister for the work that the CSIRO and the Environment Protection Agency, which brought out 10 best practice and environmental management papers in a series, have done. They can have a constructive role and, as I said, local government has a role, too. Companies have a role and the industry has a role. I think the Australian mining industry has, as the minister said earlier, done a lot in recent years to ensure that it overcomes what has been a very poor public perception of its environmental management.

As a Western Australian senator, I have had the opportunity to go to many mining operations in Western Australia, both as a private citizen prior to coming into parliament and as a senator on a number of parliamentary inquiries. Recently, I think we have all seen—I have certainly seen—the enormous effort mining companies have put into environmental management. As I said earlier, that technology is intellectual property that Australia can export to the rest of the world.

The resolution of these matters as pertains to the disaster that took place at Northparkes recently will, as I said, have a silver lining to it. It will ensure that management of tailings dams will need to be better in the future. It will ensure that, where a company is required not to allow cyanide levels to reach toxic states, that will have to be more closely monitored. It will ensure that when tailings dams are built the floors of those dams, whether they be clay or some sort of plastic, are not going to be penetrated and cause risk to the environment.

In conclusion, the sorts of things that happened at Northparkes should never have to happen, but in the real world they do happen. It is a matter of how we can learn from these things and how working together with industry, with companies and with other levels of government can ensure that they do not happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief remarks on this particular matter, first of all, because these events occurred in my home state of New South Wales but, secondly, and more generally, because I believe we can learn something about the development of environmental policy in all areas from this unfortunate incident at Northparkes.

PARA.TAB: It has been said to the Senate many times, but it bears repeating, that goldmining is an extraordinarily valuable industry as far as this country is concerned. If you take steaming coal and coking coal together, they are our No. 1 export at $8 billion, but gold is our No. 2 export at $5.3 billion every year. It is a major industry and one that is certainly not going to go away and one that we should be quite rightly concerned about.

There has been enormous growth in gold mining. For example, in Australia in 1987-88 there were 119 tonnes of gold mined. This has gone up to about 260 tonnes of gold in 1994-95. There is tremendous growth in goldmining in Australia, quite apart from its significance as an export. I think some history will help us better understand the unfortunate circumstances that happened with North Ltd's Northparkes mine where some 2,000 birds, the company itself has admitted, were killed by its tailings dam—2,000 birds which included significant numbers of endangered species.

You have to go back to the introduction of the gold tax in 1986, something which I remember very clearly because I was working as a stockbroker at the time and I was buying and selling mining company shares. What happened in 1986 when the Labor government decided to introduce a gold tax or proper taxation on gold companies was that there was an enormous scramble amongst gold mining companies to mine very high grade ore. That rush continued from 1986 until 1990 when the tax was finally effected.

What then happened was that these companies had to find some way to maintain their earnings for their shareholders and they had to mine lower and lower grades of ore. To give you an example of that, in 1986 it was reasonable for a mine to be mining some five grams per tonne of gold in its ore. That is a very tiny amount of gold and a very large amount of ore.

If you look at what is happening today, the Telfer mine, which is a major mine, is now operating on just over one gram per tonne and it has been able to do that with the increasing use of more sophisticated technology. In this case, it is cyanide leaching technology. Cyanide, to anyone, is a highly reactive substance and is very dangerous, indeed. There has been pressure, in other words, on the gold companies to use new technology and this has led to the sorts of risks we have today.

The problem will not go away. ABARE has forecast there is increasing demand for gold. It is a major source of export earnings. Companies have to maintain their dividends so it is natural that there will be an increasing use of technology to deliver these sorts of results. I think that is the point from which we should take some lessons.

What we need to do is better understand how industry works to come at these problems not just from the environmental protection angle, which is where this problem has landed in our lap, or from heritage considerations where people are concerned about the value of the natural environment but also to anticipate what companies are going to do—what sort of technologies they are going to use which are going to lead to these sorts of degradations. In that respect, the motion before the Senate is entirely appropriate because unless we address things in this fashion what we will have is the perpetual situation where we are closing the door after the horse has bolted and that serves no-one any good at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, what statements were made by the government on 7 August 1995 in conjunction with the managing director of North Ltd may well have been a public relations invention. As that was happening, North knew about its own tailings dam and it was saying things about international best practice. The reality is quite different.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about today is not an isolated incident. We have had mentioned by a number of people other dams in which birds have died. SPEECH.PARA: KALGOORLIE CONSOLIDATED GOLD MINES (KCGM) FIMISTON 2 TAILS STORAGE EXTENSION

1.The Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) is aware that the Fimiston II tailings storage area is seeping water. The DEP has not, however, received any advice or evidence to suggest that Fimiston II is impeding exploration activities . . .

PARA.TAB: If a small miner in those areas breaches environmental conditions, someone is down on them like a ton of bricks. The reality is that this is happening again and again. From the Greens' point of view, any action that takes place must firstly recognise the extent of the problem in Western Australia in particular and right across the country. Secondly, that recognition must go beyond a public relations exercise and make sure that in the future communities and the environment will be looked at seriously and that urgent action is taken, not just a glossing over. SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE AUGUST 1995 REPORT OF THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS AND SECURITIES ON THE FIRST CORPORATE LAW SIMPLIFICATION BILL 1995
Introduction

1. The First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1994 (the Bill) was introduced in the House of Representatives on 8 December 1994. On 8 February 1995, the House of Representatives referred the Bill to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities (the Committee) for consideration and an advisory report. The Committee's report was tabled in the House of Representatives on 2 March 1995. The House of Representatives subsequently amended the Bill to take account of the Committee's recommendations.

2. The Bill was introduced into the Senate on 23 March 1995. On 23 August 1995, the Senate referred Items 1 to 4, inclusive, of Schedule 4 of the Bill to the Committee for inquiry and report. The Committee's report was tabled in the Senate on 30 August 1995.
3. The Government thanks the members of the Committee for their willingness to take the reference at short notice, and for providing their report in such a timely fashion.

4. Together with the Committee, the Government acknowledges the valuable contribution made by those persons who appeared before the Committee to give evidence, and who provided written submissions to the inquiry.

5. Items 1-4 of Schedule 4 to the Bill introduces a new distinction between large and small proprietary companies. The concepts of exempt and non-exempt proprietary companies are to be abolished. Currently, exempt proprietary companies must prepare annual accounts, but are not required to have them audited or lodged with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). A non-exempt proprietary company must lodge audited accounts with the ASC. (A proprietary company whose shares are held by a public company or a foreign company is non-exempt.)
6. The Bill will require large proprietary companies to lodge audited accounts with the ASC. A proprietary company will be `large' if it satisfies at least two of the following three criteria:
the consolidated gross operating revenue for the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is $10 million or more
the value of the consolidated gross assets at the end of the financial year of the company and the entities it controls (if any) is $5 million or more
the company and the entities it controls (if any) have 50 or more employees at the end of the financial year.

7. Under Corporations Law subsection 313(2), the Commission may relieve a company from compliance with specified requirements of the Law relating to the audit of accounts. Corporations Law subsection 313(11) defines the circumstances in which the Commission may make an order under subsection 313(2). They include the circumstance where compliance with the requirements would impose unreasonable burdens on the company or a class of companies. Therefore, if to require certain large proprietary companies to comply with the audit requirements of the Law would impose unreasonable burdens on those companies, the Commission will be able to make an order relieving those companies of the obligation to comply with those requirements.
8. The Committee noted concerns that the audit requirement to be imposed on large proprietary companies by the Bill may not be justified in some cases.
9. The Committee made the following recommendation to address this concern:
Recommendation 1

The Bill be amended to provide that in exercising its discretion under section 313 of the Corporations Law to exempt a large proprietary company, or class of large proprietary companies, from the audit requirement the Australian Securities Commission should have regard to, but not be limited by, the following criteria:
the expected cost or burden of audit;
the expected public interest or benefit of making this information available;
the number of creditors;
the nature and extent of a company's liabilities;
whether it is the first year the company is required to prepare audited accounts;
whether the company is one which is likely to repeatedly move in and out of the large proprietary category over a period of years.'

10. The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation. It proposes that the Bill be amended to require the ASC to have regard to the matters identified by the Committee in the exercise of its discretion to relieve a large proprietary company of the requirement to have its accounts audited.

11. The Committee indicated in its report that it anticipates that the ASC will exercise by way of a class order its discretion to exempt large proprietary companies from the requirement to appoint an auditor. The Chairman of the ASC, Mr Cameron, indicated to the Committee that if the Bill were passed in its present form the ASC would engage in full public consultation to identify appropriate classes, which would in turn be publicly exposed for comment. The Committee made the following recommendation:
Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends that the exercise of the ASC's discretionary power in the manner described in Recommendation 1 be made subject to a process of public consultation and scrutiny. The Committee also recommends that the ASC include in its Annual Report details of how it has complied with its procedures.

12. The Government agrees that class orders should be made following a transparent consultation process, and that the ASC should include details of this in its annual reports. The Chairman of the ASC has advised the Attorney-General that in the exercise of this discretion the ASC would adopt a process of public consultation and scrutiny.

13. The Committee considered that the small/large distinction and the criteria for granting exemptions should be examined in the light of their application in practice and of the need to ensure that companies of significant economic importance meet higher reporting standards. It also considered that the cost to the commercial community of the exemption process should be reviewed. The Committee made the following recommendation:
Recommendation 3

The three tests contained in the proposed section 45A, the criteria for exercising the ASC's discretion, the exercise of that discretion and the effectiveness and cost of the process be reviewed by the government and this Committee after a period of two years.
14. The Government agrees that these matters should be reviewed after a period of two years.

15. The Committee considered that a large proprietary company may face difficulties in meeting the audit obligation if the obligation is imposed some time after the commencement of the company's financial year. The Committee made the following recommendation:
Recommendation 4

In view of the delay in the commencement of the legislation, the Committee recommends that the Bill be amended to defer the commencement of the audit obligation on large proprietary companies until the 1996-97 financial year.

16. The Government acknowledges the Committee's concern, and proposes to amend the Bill to provide that the first financial year for which large proprietary companies must have their accounts audited is the first financial year that starts after the commencement of the relevant provisions of the Bill.

17. Currently, exempt proprietary companies are not required to lodge their accounts with the ASC if they appoint an auditor. Some of these companies will be large proprietary companies after the Bill is enacted, and will therefore have to lodge audited accounts with the Commission. To avoid undue disruption to the commercial arrangements of these companies, the Bill proposes that existing proprietary companies which have their annual accounts audited, which are large and which elect to continue operating under the existing rules (`grandfathered companies') will not need to lodge their accounts with the ASC (proposed subsection 317B(3)).

18. The Committee supported proposed subsection 317B(3) in its report of 2 March 1995. However, the Committee reconsidered the matter in light of the evidence presented during its recent reference. In its report of 30 August, the Committee referred to concerns that proposed subsection 317B(3) would allow a business already being audited, and coming within the large category, to be indefinitely exempted from lodging financial statements. The Committee made the following recommendation:
Recommendation 5

Whilst not within the Committee's terms of reference, the Committee considers that the proposed section 317B(3) (the "grandfathering" clause) in the Bill be amended to include a sunset period of three years from the date of commencement of the legislation.

19. The Government notes that Recommendation 5 was not within the Committee's terms of reference, and that persons who would be adversely affected by this recommendation were not given an opportunity to comment on the issue.
For this reason, the Government considers it would not be appropriate at this stage to amend the Bill to include a sunset period for proposed subsection 317B(3).

20. However, the Government recognises the need to closely monitor the impact of proposed subsection 317B(3) on affected persons and companies. The Government therefore proposes that the operation of subsection 317B(3) be reviewed after it has been in force for two years. This could occur as part of the same review, recommended by the Committee and accepted by the Government, of the operation of the small/large distinction for proprietary companies.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 10, page 31, item 1, proposed subsection 52(1), omit all words before paragraph (a), substitute:
"`(1) The Designated Authority must, from time to time, but not less frequently than every 12 months, prepare a document setting out particulars of:".

This bill is an incredibly complex area of legislation because it is an amending bill, amending a 1982 bill which itself has a number of schedules. Parts of this proposed legislation impact on other legislation. Some of it is picked up elsewhere, in matters not strictly before us today. But, in discussion on the amendments I will be moving on behalf of Senator Kernot, some of these other bits of legislation will be mentioned. That is the reason it has been rather difficult to get a handle on some of this.

PARA.TAB: The first amendment goes to schedule 10 on page 31 of the amending bill. From time to time we will need to refer to pages and sections in the original legislation as well. The clause in the amending bill proposes omitting the subsection, substituting words to the effect that the designated authority must from time to time, as soon as it is practicable to do so, prepare a document setting out a number of particulars, which it lists. Our amendment is to the effect that the designated authority must from time to time, but not less frequently than every 12 months, prepare a document setting out certain particulars.

The reason for this is that there has been a lack of information in the past in relation to those matters—permits granted or authorities given, refusals to grant permits and so on. As this is an area of a great deal of interest to people concerned about wildlife protection, exports and imports, we thought that it was appropriate that a time be put in there so that this simply cannot drift on—that there would be a regular reporting requirement which would allow everybody to have access to the information and, therefore, have an input to that.

The amendment as we put circulated had a six-month reporting requirement. We have had some discussion with staff from the minister's office. They suggested a 12-month period, and the Democrats have changed the amendment as circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to, in a sense, support the sentiments that were expressed by Senator Coulter. Views have been put to me by a variety of groups—I think the World Wildlife Fund for Nature was one of them—that there is a need for a more ordered procedure. The current act, as it stands, says `the designated authority must, from time to time, as soon as it is practicable to do so, prepare a document', and I think that is a little bit vague.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, views have been put to me that six months is perhaps unduly restrictive. We feel that there needs to be order and certainty in this process. So, as the Democrats now propose a 12-month reporting requirement, we would support such a requirement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government amendment set out in schedule 10 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Amendment Bill 1995 will require the designated authority to publish reports outlining the details of permits and authorities, whether granted or refused, on an ad hoc basis.

PARA.TAB: While I recognise the concern that details of the trade in wildlife be made available to the public, the cost of publishing the particulars of every permit and authority in the Commonwealth Gazette, as is currently required under the act, is prohibitive. The effect of the government's current amendment will be that reports can be produced at regular intervals and at minimal cost. So the government is prepared to accept the Democrats' amendment on the basis that the reporting period be 12 months rather than six months. This will also ensure reporting compatibility with other requirements such as the reporting requirements of the ANCA annual report and the CITES annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate the support of the Greens for the Democrats' amendment and also—presuming that what the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has just said is that the phrase will actually be `not less frequently than every 12 months'—to indicate support for that change. It does not exclude the possibility that the report can come in less time than the 12 months; it just does not put that onus on the designated authority.

PARA.TAB: Having said that we support it, I just wanted to flag to you, Madam Temporary Chair, that the Greens have three amendments, two of which are opposition to clauses, so they are not technically amendments. I just wanted to make you aware of that, as we are going through, in case dealing with the Democrats' amendments in a clump allows that to be overlooked.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—I also understand, Senator Chamarette, that as well as your two parts that you are in opposition to, in schedule 4 and schedule 6, your amendment No. 3 is to the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 6, not No. 8, as was previously set out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to what I said earlier. I accept what the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has just said. In discussions with his officers, I did put it to them that with the development of better database systems the cost of publishing all the information might well be reduced. Very often what people are requiring is a small amount of information to trigger an inquiry for the full information. I understand that is also in preparation. So that, over time, should make this process easier to handle.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.After schedule 1, page 3, insert the following schedule:
"SCHEDULE 1ASection 3
CONSIDERATION TO BE GIVEN TO
THE VIEWS OF CONCERNED PERSONS

TAB.TAB: Insert:

PARA.TAB: `and (c)applications for a permit to export Schedule 1 specimens under section 28; and

TAB.TAB: (d)applications for a permit to re-export Schedule 1 specimens under section 32; and
(e)applications for a permit to import Schedule 1 specimens under section 36.'.

SPEECH.PARA: Insert:
`or(c)grant a permit to export Schedule 1 specimens under section 28; or

(e)grant a permit to import Schedule 1 specimens under section 36.'.

This series of amendments would allow for a one-month public comment period on applications to import or export schedule 1 species; that is, CITES appendix 1 species and certain other native endangered species. Schedule 1 contains taxa believed to be threatened with extinction. The public has a legitimate interest in ensuring that any proposed import or export of these species would not further endanger them.

PARA.TAB: The amendments are consistent with the CITES requirements. We believe it is in the public interest and is also in the best interests of the species. There is a growing trend in the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act to allow for public comment; that is, the introduction of public comment periods for management programs in a previous amendment act and for alterations to schedule 6 in the 1995 amendment act.

It is also complementary to and consistent with measures under the Commonwealth Endangered Species Protection Act. The amount of import and export of schedule 1 species is not large. So the somewhat obscure wording here is to give effect to that requirement, and it will allow for a public comment period. I put that amendment to the committee.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be agreeing with this proposal. The act provides for public comment where the minister or designated authority has a discretionary power. I agree that it is appropriate in those circumstances for public consultation. In terms of this proposal, however, the minister has no discretion, either for imports or exports of schedule 1 material.

PARA.TAB: There are strict requirements specified in the current provisions of the act regarding the export and import of schedule 1 material. For example, there are a number of requirements which must be met in a case where an individual wishes to import elephant ivory, which is listed in schedule 1. The ivory must have been obtained prior to CITES controls taking effect—that is, prior to 1976. The import must not be for any commercial purpose. The management authority of the country of export must have issued a CITES export permit, and that permit must confirm that the ivory was pre-CITES. Once these matters are fully met, a permit to import might be granted.

A public comment period will not assist me in making a decision on applications to trade in schedule 1 material. The designated authority has the expertise to advise me on whether the conditions that are stipulated in the act are met or not. So the government will not be agreeing with the proposal. As I have indicated, the act provides no discretion to the minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) support the amendment put by Senator Coulter. I am disappointed that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has indicated that the government does not support it. I note he said it would not assist him in his process, but I think the real aim of the amendment is to ensure public participation in the process. I think that is a very important component of any piece of legislation, no less with bills that deal with the care of the environment.

PARA.TAB: Because this area of wildlife protection is widespread and diverse, the ability for the community to scrutinise the suitability of persons and organisations to receive permits to engage in export, re-export and import of species is, we believe, of paramount importance to ensure government accountability. It is also a way of gathering information about practices in the community. We indicate our support for the amendment and hope the opposition has given this due consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I notice in relation to Senator Chamarette's comments that there is the heading `Consideration be given to the views of concerned persons'. I understand the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) to say that under this bill he does not have discretion on receipt of particular advice. As I understood the amendment as moved, the minister, apart from having to consider the advice from the designated authority, will have to consider the advice of concerned persons. The minister said he has legal advice that he does not have discretion once he has received advice from the designated authority.

PARA.TAB: My advice on this is the same as the minister's advice. I understand that that happens to be the case. Therefore, we will not be supporting the amendment. If at a later stage further information becomes available to me that shows that the information I have been given is not correct, when happy days are here again and the government has been changed this matter could be revisited.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Schedule 14, page 43, item 4, at end of proposed section 57W, add the following subsection:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Majority of members not to represent any one body or group.

SPEECH.PARA: "'(5)The Minister must ensure that persons representing any one interest body or group do not constitute a majority of the members of the Exotic Birds Committee.'.".

This amendment is to schedule 14 and page 43 of the amending bill. This schedule sets out, among other things, the appointment of members to the Exotic Birds Committee. It says `to be appointed by the Minister by written instrument' and has the headings `Qualifications of Chairperson of Committee' and `Qualifications of other members of Committee'.

PARA.TAB: We are seeking to add a fifth subclause to that appointment because we are concerned that in relation to this Exotic Birds Committee—I think senators who have received approaches on this matter would be aware of this fact—there are some fairly strong forces at work in relation to the commercial and pet use of exotic birds which may well be in conflict with the interests of birds, the conservation of birds and various other aspects, such as the introduction of exotic diseases and so forth.

The concern which we have is that it should not be possible for the Exotic Birds Committee to become dominated by any one interest group. For that reason, we have moved the addition of the following subclause:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister must ensure that persons representing any one interest body or group do not constitute a majority of the members of the Exotic Birds Committee.
I point out that proposed subsection (4), which would come immediately before this if the committee were minded to accept this amendment, says:
The Minister must ensure that persons employed by the Commonwealth or authorities of the Commonwealth do not constitute a majority of the members of the Exotic Birds Committee.

The government is already accepting the idea that there should not be a dominance of persons employed by the Commonwealth or authorities of the Commonwealth. We are seeking to extend that so that it becomes a proper multi-interest body without any one particular interest body being able to dominate and constitute a majority and therefore dominate the voting on this body. After all, this is quite an important plank in this piece of legislation. For those reasons, I strongly urge the committee to accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter is right: this is an important body. Like Senator Coulter, I have had the opportunity to receive representations and to speak to quite a range of people who are involved in this area. The reality is that there is a significant diversity of views on some issues. I understand that as the debate has proceeded to date there have been extensive consultations with the department of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). Certainly, I have had a chance to speak to a number of aviculture bodies that have expressed a variety of concerns.

PARA.TAB: I would like to hear the minister's views on how he would propose that such a body be composed. We are speaking of interest groups, and it strikes me that there are a number of interest groups within the aviculture area and groups which perhaps give a particular emphasis to issues which may not be shared to the same extent by other groups. I look forward to hearing the minister's response on that issue. There was some initial concern that the views of specialists in this area may not have been given due weight in the advice of particular species to be registered. I would be interested to hear the minister's response to Senator Coulter's comments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concerns that have been raised about the composition of the Exotic Birds Committee, which will provide advice to me on the administrative aspects of this scheme. I can provide to senators the commitment that all relevant interest groups will be represented on the Exotic Birds Committee and, in particular, that aviculture interests will be fully accommodated.

PARA.TAB: I recognise that the scheme directly impacts on aviculture and that the aviculture community should be provided with every opportunity to be an active participant in the administrative and policy making process. The committee will have at least 13 members and may not have a majority of Commonwealth officers, nor is the chairperson allowed to be an officer of the Commonwealth.

Avicultural and zoological associations and organisations, conservation and welfare groups will all be represented on the committee. No group will have a majority on the committee. But as the avicultural community is significantly affected by the scheme, it is important that it has significant representation. I cannot stipulate a percentage of representation, as that of course will depend on my assessment of individuals nominated for the committee.

To go to the amendment as moved by Senator Coulter, the Exotic Birds Committee is to be set up under the proposed amendments to the act as part of the regulation of the possession of classified birds scheme provisions. The essential function of the committee is to advise me on matters relating to the operation of the exotic birds provisions of the act. As I have said, the committee will consist of a chairperson and 12 other members. But membership of the committee will be at my discretion, with the proviso that each member should possess relevant qualifications, experience or expertise.

Senator Coulter raises concerns in relation to possible domination, if you like, of the committee. But given the genesis of the bird registration scheme and the function of the Exotic Birds Committee, it is obviously not in my best interests as the minister to be advised by a group which is biased in favour of one view—be that oriented towards aviculture, commercial interests or animal welfare.

Accordingly, I can accept the amendment that has been moved by Senator Coulter. I hope the assurance that I have been able to give Senator Kemp does allay some of his concerns in relation to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think that the minister has given some assurances which will provide some comfort at least to a number of groups that have made contact with me. They were concerned that the aviculturists would have a strong representation on the committee and, it would follow from that, that they would have an important role in the decision making process. My memory of what the minister said gave some comfort to that position.

PARA.TAB: Also, it is recognised that there will be diversity of groups with diversity of interests on that committee. But in the light of the assurances that the minister has given, we would be prepared to accept the amendment which has been moved by Senator Coulter.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Schedule 15, page 57, item 4, omit the item, substitute the following items:
"4.Subsection 53(2):
Omit the subsection.
Omit `made under subsection (2) or (3)', substitute `made under subsection (3)'.".
This is where we start to get a bit complicated. Turning to page 52 of the 1982 act, we find section 53 which deals with the possession of illegally imported specimens. Section 53(2) states:

PARA.TAB: On the prosecution of a person for an offence against subsection (1), being an offence to which paragraph (1)(a) applies, it is a defence if the person proves that he or she did not know, and had no reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting, that the specimen in the person's possession had been imported in contravention of this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to page 57 of the amending bill which is before us, proposed subsection 53(2) suggests that we omit `in the person's possession'. It would then read: `had no reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting that the specimen had been imported in contravention of this act. We suggest here that this subsection be omitted'.

PARA.TAB: We also suggest that `made under subsection (2) or (3)' be omitted and `made under subsection (3)' placed in substitution. Subsection (3) states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . prosecution of a person for an offence against subsection (1), being an offence to which paragraph (1)(b) applies, it is a defence if the person proves that the specimen was not imported in contravention of this Act.

We argue here that this deletion of `in the person's possession' should not hold. In other words, there is a sort of a double negative involved in this amendment. It is difficult to know precisely why the government is seeking to delete those words `in the person's possession' which preface `had been imported in contravention of this Act'. We suggest that that section be retained. The second part of this, being 4A which relates to proposed subsection 53(4), is simply consequential upon the earlier section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter, I listened very carefully. I opened up all my acts, including the original, and I noted how you skipped so quickly and freely between the amending bill and the original act. I applied every one of my powers of legal understanding to finding out what you were driving at. As I read subsection 53(2), which you wish to omit, it states:

PARA.TAB: On the prosecution of a person for an offence against subsection (1), being an offence to which paragraph (1)(a) applies, it is a defence if the person proves that he or she did not know, and had no reasonable grounds for knowing or suspecting, that the specimen in the person's possession had been imported in contravention of this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not a criminal lawyer, but it does seem to me that, as I understand it, if a person did not know they were in contravention of the act and did not understand that they were breaking the law—and one can easily hypothesise particular cases where such a thing would occur—unless you can provide me with perhaps greater clarity to support an amendment along these lines, under criminal law such a clause is generally regarded as a defence or at least a mitigating circumstance. I wonder whether you could revisit that and perhaps explain with greater clarity what you are attempting to drive at.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. In the way that a person who breaks the speed limit on the road and endangers the lives of others is not permitted to argue that he or she did not know the speed limit was 80 or 110, because it is regarded as an offence which should be punishable simply because the offence is sufficiently serious in that it imposes a risk to others and lack of knowledge of the law in that case is not a defence, in a similar way we are seeking in this legislation—and I simply go back to the title of the bill—wildlife protection. We are not trying to seek here the protection of people who traffic in wildlife, or anything else. We are seeking wildlife protection.

PARA.TAB: For instance, if a species is endangered and somebody does something in contravention of this legislation which further endangers that species, their lack of knowledge of what they have done does not alter the effect of what they have done. The effect is to further endanger the wildlife. If we are serious about protecting the wildlife, then we should be serious about ensuring that those people are brought to book, whether or not they had that knowledge.

The listing of various schedules and so on is there if people are involved in this sort of trading. This is a sufficiently serious matter in a country which, for our population, has had more extinctions of many vertebrate and invertebrate species, particularly mammal species, than any other country. We are dealing with wildlife protection. I think that is the justification I would put—that there is an absolute in here which overrides the rights of people, and ignorance of the law should not be a defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on this before the minister speaks so as to gain clarification as to whether I have understood the situation correctly. It is the Greens' intention to support the Democrat amendment. We believe the removal of that section does avoid any interpretation that ignorance is a defence, in a light way, as Senator Coulter has pointed out, because of the implications of the act.

PARA.TAB: However, my understanding is that its removal from this legislation does not mean that under common law a person cannot actually have as a defence the excuse that they were unaware and be able to use that if they were in a situation in which they could be challenged. It is on that basis that I would also feel the same concern expressed by Senator Kemp, if we were saying that nobody could claim they did not know about it and their level of knowledge or lack of knowledge was not able to be used as an argument mitigating the consideration that was being given to them.

The understanding is that it does not deprive them of their common law right but simply deprives this act of a position which in some way undermines what we are trying to do—which is to say that it is very important we deal with the protection of wildlife, and that emphasises the importance of that within the act and does not give a kind of escape clause that is also written into it. So, on that basis—and I would like the minister's clarification that this does not go against the principle of the common law of not knowing being a defence—we support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my understanding also. I will go a little further and say that, clearly, if you are dealing with a particular case, the seriousness with which a breach of the law is considered by a court would take into account those very facts. Whether in fact it was a defence in an absolute sense or not, nonetheless the court would clearly give some weight to the circumstances, and the circumstances might be that the person had no way of knowing. But, as Senator Chamarette has pointed out, to write it in here as an absolute defence is simply going too far when the purpose of the bill is the protection of wildlife—and I come back to that point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand this amendment is proposed by the Democrats as part of a package to address the trade in oriental medicines within Australia and it aims to remove any defence of ignorance of the law as it would apply to the possession of oriental medicines. It is my view that the existing subsection 53(2) in no way offers such a defence. The defence that the existing subsection 53(2) offers is ignorance of the illegal importation. In other words, the defendant has to prove that they had no criminal intention in relation to the offence.

The effect of Senator Coulter's amendment would be to remove this defence capability from the defendant, thereby leaving the defendant open to prosecution regardless of whether criminal intent existed in the mind of the defendant. Considering the high level of penalty that is available under section 53—five years imprisonment or a fine of $100,000—it would be most inappropriate to remove this defence provision from the act. The particular concerns that have been raised with us relate very much to therapeutic goods, as has been mentioned, and the fact that there is still a very flourishing trade in relation to oriental medicine, particularly Chinese medicine. A number of the products which are offered for sale contain, or purport to contain, a number of CITES-listed species such as bear, leopard, musk, deer, rhino or tiger, and this has already been mentioned. That constitutes one of the principal threats to a continuing survival of those animals in the wild.

PARA.TAB: A number of factors were found to be contributing to this illegal trade, including inadequate levels of targeted law enforcement effort, confusing non-comprehensive laws for the possession and domestic sale of illegally imported endangered species and the lack of a coordinated and culturally sensitive education campaign, which is something that Senator Chamarette has already mentioned, to inform the traditional and Chinese medicine using community of the legal and conservation implications of the continued importation and use of endangered species medicines.

The concern here is that there is an element involved in the offering for sale of these materials, which is in itself a great stimulus to the continued exploitation of these species and which goes beyond the mere possession. At our recent meeting with you in Canberra, during the Peak Conservation Organisations week, we discussed the issue of exporting live native freshwater fish.

This corrected an anomaly which permitted such exports, despite a longstanding Commonwealth prohibition on exporting live native animals. We stress, that this was accepted as appropriate policy by the Wildlife Protection Authority (WPA) of ANCA. The agreement to allow exports of "captive-bred" native freshwater fish was a compromise agreed to by TRAFFIC and WWF, in order to secure the export ban.

On February 1st, HSI received a draft proposal from WPA, prepared by the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industry and Fisheries, for approval to export live native freshwater fish for commercial purposes (for the export aquarium fish trade). Apart from the fact that the application is for a "Controlled Specimens", and not for a full "Approved Management Program", which, in the view of HSI, is not acceptable for live native fauna, this appeared to be in direct contradiction with the agreed amendments to the Wildlife Protection Act, currently awaiting passage through Parliament. ANCA had often mentioned to us that they were concerned for the practicalities of implementing an essential ban of live native freshwater fish exports, though HSI did not agree that there were any insurmountable problems.

Part of the reason for HSI's concern for the delay in the passage of the amendments, and for which we urged your intervention, was the need to see the freshwater fish export ban imposed.

The primary reasons that ANCA now forward for omitting the amendment are as follows: 1. That it is not possible under the Act to differentiate between prohibitions on native freshwater fish and control methods for other marine fish species; 2. That such a prohibition would impede the ability of ANCA to instigate further export controls on marine fish exports; 3. That permitting such exports would lead to better conservation of native freshwater fish in Australia. ANCA now also renounced the previously and jointly agreed position that the current situation represents a legal and policy anomaly. They have taken a complete 180 degree turn in approach.
HSI rejects all these arguments—
and this is the support for these amendments. It continues:

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is indeed wide ranging, but I think we have seen recently a number of examples in which our ignorance of what we are doing has either led or potentially led to quite serious environmental consequences. We have seen recently—not in the freshwater fish area—a mass extinction of pilchards across southern Australia and a very, very detailed and intensive investigation into that has failed to prove one way or another whether that was or was not due to an exotic disease being brought in by pilchards, in this case dead pilchards.

PARA.TAB: There is a difference, if I can pick up what the minister was saying, between live fish and other animals because you necessarily are exporting a watery medium and various other quite unknown factors along with the fish. There is no other way you can export them. It is in that area of ignorance that I think we need to tread very, very carefully.

You might have seen, Senator Kemp, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, the Quantum program last Wednesday night. Among other things, it suggested that the mass extinction of frog species in the tropical rainforests of Australia may well have been due to the importation of exotic fish for aquarium specimens and, again, the introduction of a virus in the water with those fish which has then been released into streams, either deliberately or inadvertently, and has then spread a virus which is going through the amphibian population. I simply make the plea that, on the one hand, we seem to be going overboard to protect commercial interests in a situation in which we have a very poor knowledge of what we are doing, rather than adopting the precautionary principle and saying, `Look, we are really ignorant in a lot of these areas.
