TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the insertion of the item `Specimens subject to quotas'. I point out to my colleagues that this actually refers to leopard skin and leopard skin imports. Previously, leopard skin imports were illegal in Australia. As a result of the CITES management plans being completed for areas from which leopards come, we are now proposing to legalise leopard skin imports from these areas where there are the management plans. CITES recommended this. As it recommended that management plans should be in place indicating that leopards are listed as vulnerable by CITES, this amendment then says that they should therefore be available for imports.

PARA.TAB: The Worldwide Fund for Nature has informed me that the use of this particular process is primarily as trophies for people who have shot the leopards in hunting expeditions in Africa. They are then able, by this provision, to import them into the country. Essentially, we are condoning an activity overseas by facilitating the import into the country of the trophies gained in those activities.

The Greens believe that, notwithstanding CITES's decision to include Panthera pardus, the African leopard, on schedule 2 of its at-risk species list rather than on schedule 1 and approve hunting of these animals, subject to management plans and quota, for Australia to allow the importation of Panthera pardus species skins into the country constitutes implicit approval of that activity.

The hunting of leopards by Australians is usually in response to commercial safaris organised by Australian hunting and shooting groups, to send Australian people to Africa to shoot these animals in their natural, open woodland habitat for no other reason than what we would feel is gratuitous and barbaric sport. The money paid by Australian tourists in the country to take part in that activity more often than not goes straight into the hands of that country and the governments, not even to the local African landowners. We have to be aware that, while some people may say, `Barbaric though it is it assists those countries,' it does go into the hands of the country and it actually perpetuates a practice that I think on a global scale we have to evaluate in a different manner.

The leopard is one of the last of the large spotted cats left in existence and in allowing this amendment to go through, Australia would be actively participating in its march towards extinction. For that reason I urge my colleagues to oppose this schedule.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some haste that I rise tonight to make a contribution to the debate on the adjournment, breaking a longstanding rule of mine not to enter into this debate. But in the course of doing some research into the Western Australian state government's workplace agreements—the industrial relations model that the Liberal state government has adopted in Western Australia which is based on individual contracts—I came across some quite concerning information with implications for this parliament and for the federal government.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian state Liberal government has been seeking to have workers in my state take up individual contracts and move out of the award system. The government has been driving a campaign to get those workers to take out individual contracts both in the private sector and in the government sector. They have been putting a great deal of effort into that attempt.

It seems that as part of that approach the Western Australian government has come up with a concept called `flexible remuneration packaging'. At first sight that would not seem to be a particularly big deal. Many employers offer salary packaging; there is nothing intrinsically wrong with that provided appropriate taxation is paid.

Senators would be aware that this government has a proud record of introducing the fringe benefits tax which helps to ensure that all elements of a remuneration package are taxed and that the tax avoidance measures that have grown up around salary packaging have largely been eradicated. If the benefits are not taxable in the employees' hands, the employers are taxed for providing that fringe benefit.

I have discovered that the Western Australian government has been offering flexible remuneration packages to many of its higher paid and senior employees within the health sphere. These packages are offered only to selected employees and the key element in this is that they are offered only to those who sign a workplace agreement—that is, those who are prepared to opt out of the award system and accept the individual contract approach that the state government has sought to introduce.

Those employees are allowed to sacrifice up to 30 per cent of their salary package. They can take their salary in other than cash benefits up to a maximum of 30 per cent. So, for instance, an employee who agrees to move out of the award system and sign a workplace agreement can sacrifice part of their salary and have their employer—this is essentially the state government—pay their children's school fees, mortgage repayments, superannuation payments into private superannuation firms or the lease of a private motor vehicle. There is a range of other options that are available. These benefits can be provided as long as there is no increase in costs to the employer. But the employer claims that this packaging will improve the employee's total remuneration package. So you have this situation where the employer says, `By salary packaging, you will be better off, but it will be at no cost to me, the employer.'

So how is it that this inducement can be offered and a supposed advantage flow to employees without any cost to that state government, the employer of these people? Simply put, it is because of tax evasion. The state government is encouraging the avoidance of payment of tax by its employees. It has erected a tax avoidance scam. The scheme induces employees out of their award system into the workplace agreement on the basis of helping them to avoid paying the appropriate tax on their incomes. For those senators who would be—

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you work that out?
—I will get to that, Senator, because they are quite blatant about it. The documentation that the state government are circulating to employees states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act and Income Tax Assessment Act regulates and defines the type of benefits that you can package and how they are treated for taxation purposes.
Certain Health Care Units in the Government Health System are exempt from Fringe Benefits Tax, therefore flexible remuneration packaging can be an attractive option for some employees.

The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act provides that Public Benevolent Institutions (PBIs) which include some Health Care Units are exempt from payment of FBT on benefits provided to their employees. This means that employees can receive the following benefits on a NO FBT and NO PAYE Tax basis.

So the state government are quite clear that this is an attempt to avoid the proper payment of tax offered to select employees who will enter into their particular ideological scheme. It is aimed at getting people under workplace agreements and out of the general award system. It is a clear abuse of the public benevolent institution status of these health care units that the state government controls.

PARA.TAB: The state government are encouraging the avoidance of the payment of tax by their employees. They are deliberately setting up a scheme that will allow those employees to reduce the taxation that they would properly pay to the Australian Taxation Office based on their income.

The state government use the example in their literature of an employee whose current salary is $55,000 per annum. They point out that the current tax payable by that employee would be $17,222. But they say that, under their remuneration package that they will offer them, the tax payable will only be $9,709. Therefore, as they put it, this will increase the net remuneration to the employee by $7,513 per annum.

What you have to ask is: how is that acquired? It is acquired by the evasion of that very $7,513 tax by that employee by virtue of the scheme erected by the state government. What you have is a situation where the government is constructing a system which abuses the status of those health care units and allows the employees to benefit, but only if they are prepared to enter into the workplace agreement scheme that the state government is so desperate to encourage and to claim support for.

There is a range of federal policy concerns here that I think ought to be directed to the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), and I have today written to the Assistant Treasurer raising my concerns—firstly, about the abuse of the public benevolent institution status and, secondly, on the effect of this in terms of the reduction in taxation to the Commonwealth.

The whole question of a tax evasion strategy being given the imprimatur of a state government, I think, is of serious concern. It reduces the federal government's ability in its fight to make sure that all income and remuneration is properly taxed and that tax avoidance schemes are prevented from occurring.

The other important element of this is that it increases the burden on other taxpayers. It reduces the amount of tax that is flowing to the Commonwealth. That means that other taxpayers, people who are not entering into these tax avoidance schemes, are required to pay a greater share of tax to fund the social services that the Commonwealth provides. It really is a bit rich for a state government that constantly whinges about the perceived reduction in the federal revenue that flows to the states to be erecting tax evasion schemes for selected employees to pursue its ideological and industrial relations goals at the same time as complaining about the lack of federal funds.

So I think there is a range of issues that flow from this. There is also the question, I suppose, about whether this scheme is allowing people to benefit from other government benefits that otherwise they would not be eligible for. By reducing their income, they may well fall below thresholds that may make them eligible for other benefits.

In my view, there is a range of concerns about this scheme. It is not, for my part, an attack on people who have taken up this scheme. The government make it very clear that, if there were any change in the taxation arrangements or status, they would immediately pass any increase in costs or taxation on to the employees. So they have covered themselves and, I think, left the employees rather vulnerable.

It really is a very scandalous situation that we have a state government encouraging tax evasion. I know the federal coalition opposes the fringe benefits tax, but I did not know that the Liberal Party in Western Australia would go to this extent in terms of trying to avoid the proper payment of taxation by their employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard in this chamber recently quite a lot about the devastation caused by landmines. Such devastation is not just on military personnel and equipment in times of war, but mostly on civilian populations, often many years after the conflict itself has been resolved.

PARA.TAB: It is estimated that there are now over 100 million uncleared landmines in 62 countries, and these have become the scourge of innocent civilians, claiming at least 800 victims every month. In Cambodia, for example, it is estimated that one in every 236 of the entire population requires amputation of limbs after stepping on landmines, and thousands of hectares of arable land cannot be farmed in this country because of the mines.

Members of this chamber will also know that the Democrats have regularly called on government to support the growing worldwide call for a ban on the manufacture of anti-personnel landmines. I was extremely disappointed to see, as one of the government delegation in Beijing, that we were not given the support necessary from the Australian government to be able to support a total ban there; that is, a ban on the manufacture of landmines and, of course, also on the dispersal and use of them in any situation.

The federal government's stance, I am pleased to report, is out of step with the vast majority of Australians, who do want to see a total ban on these horrific devices. In a national campaign aimed at drawing Australia's attention to the appalling suffering inflicted by anti-personnel landmines, the Catholic Church circulated a petition calling for Australians to support a total ban on these landmines. That petition, which was presented to members of the government today, has over 195,000 signatures.

I have pleasure now in reading out a message to the Senate from year 2 students, 26 of them, from the Nativity Primary School at Aberfoyle Park in my home state of South Australia. We love to read and draw and write stories. It is not fair if some kids can't do that because they have no fingers or their eyes have been hurt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia's decade of the 1990s is shaping up to reveal a concerted attack on the provision of a public education system as a matter of right and community responsibility. I make it clear that the Australian Democrats regard the right to a publicly funded secular education system as a basic feature of our Australian culture. It is not just an obligation because Australia is a signatory to the Convention on the Rights of the Child; it has been and ought to remain a fundamental component of that which characterises Australian nationhood. It ought to be something for which we as a nation—a nation which espouses principles of egalitarianism and social, if not Christian, responsibility—hold proud and something that we will defend.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, this is no longer the case. We have almost thrown it away in our collective greedy mania for embracing economic rationalism as we replace the idea of public responsibility with principles of user-pays and market driven decision making. As governments spend less and less on education, schools are closed, teachers sacked and class sizes steadily increased. As schools are placed into an ever increasing bind, they turn to sponsorship and fees.

Cynically, we have state governments which are creating the legislative frameworks that are meant to facilitate public schools in becoming increasingly financed from a system of user-pays under the guise of providing greater autonomy for those very same schools. My own state of Tasmania is a good example, having recently passed a new education act. Although this act has been hailed as landmark legislation providing new opportunities for parent involvement in the decision making processes of schools, it has clearly built the slippery slope towards a user-pays education system.

Section 41.3 of this new Tasmanian education act of economic rationalism allows school principals to set and impose charges for incidental costs and expenses. The only restraint is that, where there is a school council, such levies must be approved by the council. At the time of its enactment, however, far fewer than half of the schools had school councils. Even now, few of the parents realise that one of the fundamental responsibilities of the school council is to approve the school budget, levies and charges. In the absence of such a council, the principal decides on the need for fees and how much they will be.

In some respects this sounds quite progressive; it seems like a mechanism for participatory decision making. In fact and in practice, it is a device by which the state government can off-load some of the odium of fundraising on to school councils—which in effect means the parents. There is no limit on the amount that can be imposed as levies and charges. That is supposedly the responsibility of the council, which may refuse to approve a budget. But here is the deadly punch: if the principal and the council fail to agree on the budget, it is the council which can be sacked by the minister. Moreover, there is no definition in the act of fees, levies and charges. There is no limit on the amount that can be imposed and no limit on the scope of their applicability. As the squeeze on education resources becomes tighter and tighter, the pressure for increased revenue from this source will be irresistible.

Currently such fees are voluntary, or termed as voluntary, although it is noted and indeed explained that parents are expected to pay. It is not clear just what is to happen if a levy is not paid. The act does not describe what will occur in that instance. How long will it be before these charges are regarded as compulsory? With no limit to their scope, the capacity for such fees to become an increasingly central component of school budgets is frightening for those of us who regard the provision of education as a government responsibility. Is it too cynical to predict that, just as Hilmer is potentially the vehicle for facilitating a major leap towards user-pays in all manner of local government provided functions and services, so too the new education act will signal the end of the public education system? I think that has to be a rhetorical question.

I conclude by reminding the Senate that the Democrats believe that the Australian government has a responsibility to ensure that the citizens of our various states are not hoodwinked by their state governments and led into situations such as the one that I have described in Tasmania. We believe that the Australian government has a responsibility to ensure that education is delivered to all Australian children on an equitable basis.

a performance in an educational institution
a performance for profit, being a performance in a place of public entertainment within the meaning of section 39 of the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 July 1995:

(2)(a) Who will he, or members of his delegation, be speaking to in: (a) the local community; (b) at Freeport mine; (c) non-Government organisations; (d) Indonesian authorities about the incident of human rights abuses and deaths in Freeport between July 1994 and February 1995.

(b) The briefing material provided to the Ambassador for such visits consists of internal Departmental documents, many of them classified, and the Government will not make the documents public.

(2)(a) to (d) The Ambassador and his party spoke with a wide range of contacts, including Indonesian civil and military officials, community leaders, non-government organisations, representatives of P.T. Freeport Indonesia and a large number of people in the Freeport mine area concerning the allegations of human rights abuses. Obviously, such information is particularly sensitive, and it would not be helpful, including in gaining additional information, to provide the names of such individuals.

(3)(a) The following people accompanied the Ambassador during his visit to Irian Jaya: from the Australian Embassy—Brigadier Kerry Mellor (Head of Australian Defence Staff), Mr James Batley (Counsellor), Mr Andreas Vecchiet (First Secretary), Ms Felicity Hand (First Secretary), Mr John McCumstie (Trade Commissioner), Mr Neil Collins (Acting First Secretary), Mr Ian Hunt (Second Secretary), Mr Chris Moy (Chief Petty Officer, Information Assistant to the Defence Attache) and Mr Mohammed Husen (Public Affairs Officer). (b) and (c) In the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, Mr Andreas Vecchiet and Ms Felicity Hand have responsibility, within the Political and Economic Branch, for Irian Jaya issues, including matters relating to human rights in the province, and Mr Denis Fisher has overall responsibility at Director level for Indonesia issues, including human rights, in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in Canberra.

(d) and (e) These officers were included in the visit because of their responsibilities for a range of issues of interest to Australia, including political and economic developments, trade, defence and security, development assistance, migration and public affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent press reports that the Lancelin bombing range, 120 kilometres north of Perth, is among Australian locations being examined by the United States (US) for military training:

(1)(a) Can the Minister confirm these reports; (b) is it a fact that US military representatives have approached Australian military officials about training here and have personally inspected Lancelin during a recent visit to Perth; if so, what was the outcome of that visit.

(2)(a) Has there been any exchange of notes, letters, contracts or any such agreement over allowing the US to use Lancelin as a bombing range; if not, why not; (b) at what stage are the plans and negotiations between the US and Australian militaries over using Lancelin as a bombing range; (c) what would be the arrangements for the US military to use Lancelin as a bombing range if this plan were to go ahead; and (d) would the US military have full control of the bombing range.

(3)(a) What reports, including environmental and social impact assessments, have been produced on the use of Lancelin as a bombing range; and (b) can a list of these reports be provided and will they be tabled; if not, why not.
(4) What is the Lancelin range being used for now and how would US military use differ from present use.
(5) Which specialists in the US military would be training at Lancelin.

(6)(a) Would any military personnel being trained by either the US or Australian military be using Lancelin as a training facility; and (b) can details be provided of which countries and specialities of forces.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) Government policy welcomes and encourages the use of existing range facilities within Australia by United States (US) forces. US use of our ranges contributes to the level of interoperability between the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and US armed forces, further strengthens the defence relationship between our two countries and by contributing to the support of a US presence in our region, furthers our shared interests in the stability and security of the region. In accord with this policy, US forces have used the Lancelin Range on a regular basis since 1989.

(b) The US armed forces have expressed interest in using Lancelin Range to conduct major exercises and have been briefed on the range by Australian Defence personnel. The visit to which you refer was that of the Commander of the US Seventh Fleet, Vice Admiral Clemins, who visited Lancelin Range, accompanied by members of his staff, on Wednesday 31 May 1995. Vice Admiral Clemins was escorted by the Lancelin Range Officer who briefed him on the facilities. After viewing the range from the air, Vice Admiral Clemins advised that he considered Lancelin Range not to be large enough to conduct any major exercises.

(2)(a) There have been no exchanges of notes, letters, or contracts with the US forces over the use of Lancelin as a bombing range. The majority of activities on the range have been conducted as, or associated with, combined exercises between Australian and US forces, or with the Republic of Singapore Navy (RSN) and the Royal New Zealand Navy (RNZN), in accordance with the ADF's scheduled exercise program. Occasionally, US Navy battlegroups transiting the area may request unilateral use of this range. Such requests are approved by me as required. If approved, arrangements are then made directly between US Embassy staff and Headquarters ADF. Local arrangements are made between the range management staff and other Australian military agencies, as appropriate. Use of the range by US forces is subject to full cost-recovery procedure.

(b) & (c) The present level of activity is expected to be maintained and there are currently no plans to increase the US usage of Lancelin. There will therefore be no need for additional arrangements to be put in place.
(d) No. The range is manned and controlled by Royal Australian Navy (RAN) personnel, generally with a US liaison officer in attendance when US forces are making use of the facility.

(3)(a) Two reports have been produced on Lancelin range. They are (i) Land Use and Management in the Defence Training Area at Lancelin, Western Australia, by the CSIRO Institute of Natural Resources and Environment, dated February 1990; and (ii) Acquisition by the Commonwealth of Land at Lancelin for Defence Training Purposes, produced for the Australian Property Group by Urban Focus in association with Halpern Glick Maunsell, dated October 1992.
(b) Copies of these reports have been provided to Senator Margetts separately.

(4) Lancelin is currently being used by the RAN as a Naval Gunfire Support range approximately 12 times per year, by the Army for Special Air Service and gunnery training, and by the Royal Australian Air Force for driver training.

The Royal New Zealand Navy used the range once in 1994 for Naval Gunfire Support training and the US Navy has conducted a number of exercises over recent years, including two occasions of air-to-ground bombing by aircraft from USS

ANSWER.PARA: Midway in 1989, Naval Gunfire Support training during 1992, and amphibious operations training in 1992 and 1993. In addition, the United States Navy SEALS and the Republic of Singapore Navy Diving Unit have conducted combined bilateral exercises with Australian Clearance Diving Teams at Lancelin.

PARA.TAB: (5) Currently the only US specialists who conduct training at the Lancelin Range are the US Navy SEALS and US Special Forces for an annual exercise with Special Air Service Regiment on a rotational basis.
(6) (a) Yes. These personnel are trained by Australian, and not by US, forces.
(b) A combined bilateral exercise between RAN and RSN Clearance Diving Teams, which includes training for Singaporean personnel, is conducted annually at Lancelin Range.
